title: The Mind's Eye
author: Mission of the Viyrans
filename: 102. The Mind's Eye - Mission of the Viyrans_djvu.txt

elements.text: [Part One]
Jungle sounds. Running.
There's no escape you know. (sotto) Not for any of us. (beeping) Ukarme here.
[OC]: (a woman) Report. Have you found the source of the signal?
Yes, Major Takol. It appears we have a visitor. Amale human. No suit. He was hiding in some caves near sector four north, but made a run for it when I approached.
[OC]: What are you waiting for, Trooper? Stop dawdling and track him down. Takol out.

Yes, Major. Thank you, Major. The thought hadn't occurred to me. I guess that's why you're a Major and I'm just a humble Trooper. Whoa! Look, I haven't got all day. If you don't show yourself by the count of three, I'll start shooting. One, two.
Three.
Now, don't make any sudden moves. I don't want to shoot you, but I will if you force me to.
I think I need...
Stay where you are.
A doctor. Yes, that's it. I think I need a doctor.
I'm warning you.
No, wait. I am a Doctor. Yes. Hello. I'm...
Zap, thud.
[TV]: Previously on Love MD.
[TV]: Is there anyone here?
Earth calling Peri. Earth calling Peri. Can you hear me?
Sorry. What were you saying?
I was telling you about my hot date. You weren't paying a blind bit of notice. Some best friend you are.
Oh, sorry, Ally, I was miles away.
Yeah, I noticed. I ate half your cookie right in front of you and you didn't bat an eyelid. I ask you, where's the fun in thett if it's so easy?
I didn't mean to be rude. I'll turn this off. Go on, then. Spill the beans. What was Mister Wonderful like? Tell all.
That's just it. There's nothing to tell. He never showed up.
Oh, Ally, not again.
That's the fourth this year. Still, I suppose not every girl can be as lucky as you.
(laughs) Lucky?
Mmm. Now, let's see. Nice house, a gorgeous boyfriend, a loving son...
Well, two out of three ain't bad.
Oh. Are you and Kyle still having difficulties?
If by difficulties you mean door slamming, bad language and throwing things at me, then the answer's yes. In Kyle's eyes, I'm the wicked stepmother.
I thought Mike and he had talked.

You know Mike. He may be a hard-hitter at work, but with his son, he's a pussycat. When it comes to discipline in this house, I'm the one who wears the trousers. And Kyle doesn't like that. As Mike puts it, Kyle has a problem with authority.
Which reminds me. I'd better be going. Kyle's headmaster wants to see me.
Couldn't Mike go?
Apparently, it's a mom thing. You can stay here and watch TV if you like. I shouldn't be long.
Okay.
Queen Erimem? Queen Erimem. I have come as requested.
Requested? I do not recollect...
You asked me to inform you when First Minister Malarou arrived, ma'am. Well, he is here.
Ah. Yes, I recall now. Thank you, Andree. Kindly show him in, then leave us. And take the guards with you. They can wait outside.
As you command.
Door opens.
My Queen. I came as quickly as I could.
Malarou, what news? How fare my people?
Worse and worse. There are riots in many sectors, your Highness. Massive damage to property.
And casualties?
Numerous. But no deaths reported so far, thank the gods.
Yes. And no thanks to that traitor Kharto. I still find it hard to accept that this is all one man's doing. Are you sure your information is correct?
As to whether Kharto is actually organising the rebels, I cannot say. But these riots are certainly inspired by him and his seditious speeches.

Very well. Keep me informed, Malarou. I must speak with my Generals. I can stay my hand no longer. New Cairo was built on the bones of my ancestors and made fruitful by their blood. I will not stand by and watch it descend into chaos.
Don't worry, Headmaster, I can assure you he'll be as good as gold from now on.
Door closes.
You, follow me. So, do I get an explanation or just the usual silent treatment? Is that a yes shrug or a no shrug?
Whatever.
Please, Kyle. This is the third time this month I've been called by the Headmaster's secretary.
So?

So, this is the best goddamn school in London. And unless you're whiter than white from now on you're gonna get kicked out of it. And that won't please your father very much, will it? He works his butt off earning enough money to send you here, and this is how you repay him? By starting a classroom brawl?
If he's so concerned about me, how come it's just you that turns out to bail me out?
Your dad's busy. He's got commitments, meetings...
People to see, places to go. I've heard it all before.

It doesn't mean your father isn't interested in what you do. Look, Kyle, I... I know it's hard for you, your dad having a new girlfriend, but I'm a part of Mike's life now, and yours. Can't we try to get along?
You really think you're going to be with him forever? Happy ever after?
I... I hope so.
So did Mum.
Kyle, wait!
Rewinding a tape.
Stop. Play.
[OC] Still unsure as to the precise nature of the samplified but initial test...
Stop. Fast forward five minutes, then play.
[OC] Time alone will tell. My experiments continue tomorrow. Science Officer Hayton signing off.

Stop. Record. Log continues. The latest samples of bio-tissue have all demonstrated potential, but none survived long enough under lab conditions to evaluate them fully. Further living samples will be required to...
Door opens.
Professor, we have to talk.
End recording. Don't you ever knock, Major?
Not in my own base, no. Any progress? High Command expects results, and I'd like to give them something sooner rather than later.
Wouldn't you prefer to give them something finished rather than incomplete?
Finished? Then you're getting close?
I am, but I need more samples. Where's Ukarme got to?
He's bringing in some stranger he shot. Apparently the man was babbling something about a doctor.
A doctor, eh? Intriguing. Who do you think he is, Major? Military or mercenary?
We'll soon find out. Come, I need you to bring him round.
Lunch, your Highness?
Thank you, Andree. I asked First Minister Malarou to join me but he appears to be otherwise engaged. Have his meal sent to him wherever he is.
As you command.
(approaching) My Queen?
(laughs) Wait, Andree. It seems I am to be graced with his presence after all. Set his food down.
Your Highness.
My Queen. Forgive this lamentable tardiness. I was deep in discussion with one of my aides on the... the matter we were conversing upon this morning.
Kharto, you mean?
Your Highness, perhaps we'd better discuss this another time somewhere more... private?
Thank you, Andree. You may leave us.
My Queen.
Really, Malarou. Andree has been my faithful servant for years.
Nevertheless, one cannot be too careful.
You see plots and treachery everywhere. Now, let's eat while you tell me your news. Mmm, this looks delicious.
My Queen, wait. The food taster, please.
Malarou, your concern for my health is touching, but I flatter myself I Know Kharto. He's a troublemaker, not a killer.
Just let the food taster do his job, my Queen.

Oh, very well. But do it quickly. I should like to eat my lunch while it's still vaguely hot. (claps hands.) Food tasters. I know we should respect our cultural traditions, but this is the twenty fifth century. I doubt anyone has been poisoned since the time of the Pharaohs.
And that is precisely why someone like Kharto might try it now. To surprise us.
I think you overestimate his cunning. He's the...
Clatter, gasp, coughing, thud.
Malarou, do something. He's dying!
Guards! Guards! Fetch the medi-kit, quickly.
Med-scan complete.
Well, Hayton? How is he?
Respiration normal. Pulse rate elevated but within acceptable limits. Well, well. Two hearts.
Two hearts? A cybernetic?
No, no, no. He may not be human, but he is humanoid. Alien, I'd say. It may perhaps explain how he survived so long outside without an environment suit.
Can you bring him round?
With the right equipment, the right funding and enough time, I can do pretty much anything.
(sighs) Here we go again. The ego has landed.
Oh, I know soldiers like to keep things simple. Ready, aim, fire. But science is a little more sophisticated.
You know, you're not the only expert in your field. Maybe I should get myself a new genius.
If you're thinking of Harvard Steel, forget it. He's out in the Zenori System on a long-term bio- energy project. Besides, his methods are questionable to say the least.
Maybe, but he gets results.
Listen Major, if I was allowed to conduct this research along the outlined...
I'm sorry. Would you mind lowering your voices?
Oh. It seems your patient has recovered without further intervention from you.
I don't suppose there's any chance of a cup of tea? Stun guns always leave a dry taste in my mouth.
We're fresh out of Darjeeling. Sorry.
Pity. Well then, I wonder if you'd mind answering a few questions.
When you've answered mine. First off, who are you and where did you come from?
There's a happy coincidence. Those are two of my questions too, along with where am I?
You don't know where you are?
I seem to be having some problems with my memory.
Hardly surprising. I'm frankly amazed you have any memory at all. Any longer out there in that jungle, and it would have been destroyed for good.
Hayton.
Really? I'm the Doctor, by the way.
Professor Darius Hayton at your service, and this is...
I am Major Takol of the Earth Empire Space Marines, Commander of this mission. Assuming the caves where we found you were only a temporary address, where exactly are you from, Doctor?
Oh, here and there. I'm a traveller. At least, I think so. I journey with... Peri and Erimem. Please, Major, my travelling companions, two young ladies, they must be out there in the jungle.
If they stayed in the caves there may be a chance. Major?
Of course. I'll dispatch Ukarme right away.
Ukarme?
The soldier who shot you.
Ah. I hope he's as fast on his feet as he is with his gun.
Knocking on door.
Enter.
Door opens, running.
You summoned me, your Highness?
Yes, Malarou. Have you found the people responsible for the attempt on my life?
We have made a number of arrests. Forensic tests are being conducted now.
I want to be told as soon as the results are in.
Of course, my Queen. I, er...
Is there something else?
Er, Kharto.
What of him?
He was staying at one of the houses that we raided. We couldn't ignore his presence at what was Clearly a base of rebel activities, so we, er, arrested him.
Was that wise? His arrest could be the spark the insurgents need.
As I said, we couldn't very easily arrest the others and let Kharto go free, now, could we?

That is precisely what you should have done. His supporters would have wondered why he had been spared. They would have suspected him of having done a deal with us, selling them out in order to save his own miserable skin. It might not be too late. Fetch Kharto to me. I need to speak to him face to face.
My Queen, I strongly advise against taking such a...
Make the arrangements.
As you command.
One thing I learned from my old friend the Doctor. Never miss an opportunity to look your opponent in the eyes.
The Doctor again. Is there no end to his genius. It seems he has a pearl of wisdom for every occasion.
Do not joke about the Doctor. He was... is a very good friend.
I did not mean to mock. But if he is such a good friend to you, why did he leave you?
He didn't. I left him. I think.
You think, Hayton? I need some certainty here. Is this Doctor telling the truth?
Well, he appears to be. He had no idea where he was. Think about it, Takol. If he knew anything about this planet he wouldn't have been out in the jungle unprotected, would he?
It might have been a ploy, a ruse to allay suspicion and gain entry to this base.
Not everyone has a twisted mind like yours. He'd have to be a fool or a madman to take a risk like that.
You said he was an alien. Perhaps he has a means to survive out there.
Perhaps I should cut him up and find out how he ticks.
Perhaps.
I was joking.
I wasn't. I don't trust him. If he finds out about what's going on here...
Door opens.
Ah! There you are. (door closes) I thought I heard voices.
You recovered quickly.
Yes, I've got pretty good recuperative powers for a man of my age. Any news on my companions?
Nothing yet. Ukarme is still searching for them. We'll let you know the moment we hear anything.
Thank you. This is a very impressive base, Major. I'd love to take a look around.
I bet you would.
Oh, I'd be only too happy to give you the grand tour. With your permission, Major, naturally.
Granted.
Most kind. I hope I'm not putting you out.
Not at all. This way, Doctor.
What did you say this planet was called?
Oh, it doesn't have a name. It's just listed as YT45.
So what brings a combined military and scientific mission to planet YT45?
You ask a lot of questions, Doctor.
I find it helps get answers.
Remember, Doctor, curiosity killed the cat.
Andree, if you must stay with me, kindly stand still.
I'm sorry, my Queen, but I fear for your safety. Kharto would kill you given the chance.
A chance he will be denied, Andree. I am well-guarded as you can see. But I am touched by your concern. Thank you.
I have served you all my life, my Queen, ever since I could first walk.
You have indeed been a faithful companion, Andree, one in whom I have... Wait a minute. That cannot be right.
Your Highness?
You can't have served me since you were a child. That would be, what, twenty years ago.
You've ruled New Cairo since the colony was founded over twenty five years ago.
That's not possible.
Door opens.
Ta-da! The highlight of the tour - my laboratory.
Very impressive.
Door closes.
You're too kind, Doctor. Like the rest of the base, it's just stock pre-fab. But I've tried to personalise it with my own clutter.
It looks a little less temporary than the other units.
Ah well, that's the military mind-set for you. In and out quick as you can then onto the next mission...
So what exactly is the mission this time?
Top secret, I'm afraid.
Chattering animal.
And who's this fellow? A native?
Indeed. This planet's answer to a primate. We call them Jekylls.
Jekylls?
Let's just say they have a split personality.
Well, this one seems friendly enough. Looks as bit like an oversized lemur, don't you.
Oh, he is friendly, by day. But come nightfall it's a different matter. Observe those incisors, Doctor. Lethal. And he's strong too. Oh, he could rend you limb from limb if he had a mind to.
Fascinating. But he's not your main interest here, is he?
What makes you say that?
All these plants. I suspect you of being a closet botanist.
Ah! My secret is out.
Now, let's see. A Methuselan poppy, Gavinci's strangle-weed. Very nasty. And this is... Kemsel moss?
I'm impressed. It's a pleasure to meet a fellow aficionado.
Oh, Peri's the expert. I'm merely an enthusiastic amateur. Peri. Wait, I remember now. Peri and I were looking at some flowers. Purple ones like on the plants in this terrarium.
Kyropites.
Kyropites? Is that what they're called? I've never seen anything like them before.
No one has.
They're the real reason you're here, aren't they?
What makes you think that?
Interesting. You're not denying it. Now, I wonder. Could there be some kind of connection between these plants and what happened to me out in the jungle? My memory loss?
That's quite a leap, Doctor.
But you don't sound very surprised by it. So not a leap in the dark, then.
The kyropites do seem to have an unpleasant effect on people. And on the Jekylls too.
Memory loss?
That's part of it, yes. If you'd been out there much longer it would have been far worse.
As in fatal?
I'm afraid so. A routine survey mission landed here six months ago. At first all their data was being fast-beamed home, everything normal, and then... nothing.
The survey team started dying?
Every last one of them.
And yet despite the danger, Major Takol wanted to lead a second mission here.
The military believe that these plants may have potential.
As a weapon, you mean? Why? What's so special about these kyropites?
I'll show you. Now, observe what happens when I introduce some foreign matter, in this case Heager Worms, to the kyropites in this terrarium. Don't worry, it's sealed.
Hiss.
Fascinating. Some kind of anaesthetic gas?
Precisely. Oh, don't worry. The worms will make a full recovery, I guarantee it.
But why anaesthetise your attacker? Why not simply kill him?

They need him alive. They're neurological parasites. They feed telepathically on alpha waves, usually from the local wildlife. They wouldn't get much from these little chaps, of course, but with more advanced species the results can be spectacular.
The Jekylls, you mean?
It appears they've developed some kind of symbiotic relationship. Far from pacifying the Jekylls, it makes them killers. Friendly by day, deadly at night.
But why? What purpose would that serve?
It offers protection to the plants. Some creatures are more resistant to the anaesthetic gas than others. The Jekylls make sure that they are removed from the evolutionary tree.
Unnatural selection.
Whatever you call it, that's what happened to the original survey team. And not just them. We landed here during the planet's night cycle, and lost three of our men the same way.
Horrible. So those the Jekylls leave alive, the plants send into some kind of coma.

Not a coma exactly. It's more like a deep sleep. The victims are dreaming the whole time, producing plenty of alpha waves to feed the plants. And another thing. It's as if the plants share the dream experience.
But that's incredible.
Nevertheless, that is what appears to be happening. What did you experience?
I don't think I succumbed to actual sleep, but I did feel something, a presence in my head.
Do you have any history of telepathy?
A little.
It's possible that made you less susceptible.
There's something very odd about al this. Something that doesn't add up. How can you know what happens to the victims? How can you know what goes on in their unconscious minds?
By monitoring their dreams, of course.
You can do that?
Naturally.
Ukarme here. I've found some tracks.
[OC]: Follow them. And be careful, Ukarme. I've already lost enough members of this expedition.
I didn't Know you cared, Major.
[OC]:] don't. I just don't want to blot my career record by adding to the numbers of deaths under my command column.
I'm reassured by your concern. Wait. Major, there's something here. It's a woman.
[OC]: What state is she in?
Alive, and in deep sleep. No sign of the other one.
[OC]: Get her loaded on the drone and back here right away. Full decontamination protocols for both of you.
Yes, sir.
You're seriously telling me that you have a machine capable of accessing a person's dreams?
Yes.
I didn't realise human research in these fields was so advanced.
It's not. We had help.
I see. Your machine is based on alien technology.
We traded it from the Dreamweavers of the Goyana System. Oh, excuse me. Hayton here?
[OC]: Professor, tell the Doctor that Ukarme's found one of his friends.
One? But they were together.
[OC]: Sorry, he just found one. A dark-skinned girl.
The prisoner, your Highness.
My noble and just Queen. Kharto greets you, and humbly prostrates himself before your ineffable Majesty.
Thank you, Malarou. You may leave us.
But my Queen, Kharto is...
Handcuffed and unarmed. Now, take your guards and leave us.
As you command.
You too, Andree.
I would rather stay with my Queen.
So be it. Get up, Kharto. Your fervent loyalty is impressing no one.
As you wish, my most honourable Queen.
And you can stop that too. If you must call me anything, let it be Erimem. Now, I understand you have some issues with the way things are run around here.
Some issues? You could say that. I think the future of this entire colony is in jeopardy.
Ukarme. Nice to see you again.
Doctor, Professor, she's over here.
Erimem. Was she like this when you found her?
Yes. In a deep sleep, surrounded by those plants. Are we to wake her?
Absolutely not. That would be a very dangerous to do. Any attempt at sudden withdrawal from the
dream state could cause extensive cerebral damage.
I don't understand.
Neither do I. Explain, Hayton. Those Heager Worms made a full recovery with no ill effects.

That's because we revived them almost immediately. The dreams these plants initiate are complex neurological fantasies. They feel completely real. In some respects, they are real. And the longer you're under, the harder it is to tear the mind away from that reality. Your friend here looks to be at stage two.
Stage two?

Stage one lasts only for the first few hours. There's no dreaming, just plant-induced sleep. I believe that the plant uses this time to access the victim's memories and construct a fantasy world to entrap their minds.
And stage two is when the dream world has been created, and the victim believes themselves to be awake in this fantasy.
Correct. Stage three is the penultimate stage. The plant begins to physically bond with the victim, initiating the process of absorption.
And stage four?
Death.
So, Kharto, you would do things differently, I take it?
I would. First off, stop living in the past. All these reminders of Ancient Egypt. What's the point?
To remember where we came from.
It's the twenty fifth century. The Pyramids would be dust by now had they not been encased in plastic.
But if we forget our past we lose all sense of who we are.
Who are we, then? Pale imitations of our ancient ancestors. Is that really why you came here in the first place? Is it?
I... I don't know.
You don't know?
I can't seem to remember. A temporary amnesia, nothing more. What I do know for sure is that it is I and not you who leads this colony.
Yet you cannot tell me by what right. You cannot even remember how you came to be here. No wonder the colony is on the brink of disaster.
Gunshot, gurgle, thud.
Andree! What on Earth are you doing? You... you've killed him.
And you, my Queen, will be next.
Erimem. Erimem, can you hear me?
Don't, Doctor. You mustn't.
But if we can just get her to wake up... Surely there are stimulants you can use.

Haven't you been listening to what I've been saying? These are more than dreams, they're complex controlled simulacrums of real life. Look at the med-schematics. Wild variations in her heartbeat, irregular breathing patterns, massive alpha wave activity. That's not normal for a sleeping person. As far as she's concerned, her dreamscape is real.
But what if something happened to her in the dream world? If she fell off a cliff, drowned?
If she dies in the dream, she will die here in the lab too.
Andree, think about it. My death will achieve nothing. You'll be dead before you can leave the building. Another martyr to the cause like poor Kharto here.
I care nothing for the cause. Last year when Kharto first began to speak out, there was a rally, an open meeting of people who were unhappy about your rule.
I do not remember.
The Royal Guard arrived to break up the meeting, but that wasn't enough for you. You wanted to make an example of the malcontents. You ordered the guards to start firing into the crowd.
No, I would never...
They gunned down forty men and women, my parents included.
I refuse to believe it.
They showed no mercy, and neither will I. I failed in my first attempt, to poison you.
The food taster. You mean that was you?
This time you will not be so lucky. Goodbye, your Majesty.
No. Andree, please!
Shots fired.

ALLY: Couldn't Mike go?
PERI: Apparently, it's a mom thing. You can stay here and watch TV if you like. I shouldn't be long.
ALLY: Okay.
ANDREE: Queen Erimem? Queen Erimem. I have come as requested.
ERIMEM: Requested? I do not recollect...
ANDREE: You asked me to inform you when First Minister Malarou arrived, ma'am. Well, he is here.
ERIMEM: Ah. Yes, I recall now. Thank you, Andree. Kindly show him in, then leave us. And take the guards with you. They can wait outside.
ANDREE: As you command.
MALAROU: My Queen. I came as quickly as I could.
ERIMEM: Malarou, what news? How fare my people?
MALAROU: Worse and worse. There are riots in many sectors, your Highness. Massive damage to property.
ERIMEM: And casualties?
MALAROU: Numerous. But no deaths reported so far, thank the gods.
ERIMEM: Yes. And no thanks to that traitor Kharto. I still find it hard to accept that this is all one man's doing. Are you sure your information is correct?
MALAROU: As to whether Kharto is actually organising the rebels, I cannot say. But these riots are certainly inspired by him and his seditious speeches.
ERIMEM: Very well. Keep me informed, Malarou. I must speak with my Generals. I can stay my hand no longer. New Cairo was built on the bones of my ancestors and made fruitful by their blood. I will not stand by and watch it descend into chaos.
PERI: Don't worry, Headmaster, I can assure you he'll be as good as gold from now on.
PERI: You, follow me. So, do I get an explanation or just the usual silent treatment? Is that a yes shrug or a no shrug?
KYLE: Whatever.
PERI: Please, Kyle. This is the third time this month I've been called by the Headmaster's secretary.
KYLE: So?
PERI: So, this is the best goddamn school in London. And unless you're whiter than white from now on you're gonna get kicked out of it. And that won't please your father very much, will it? He works his butt off earning enough money to send you here, and this is how you repay him? By starting a classroom brawl?
KYLE: If he's so concerned about me, how come it's just you that turns out to bail me out?
PERI: Your dad's busy. He's got commitments, meetings...
KYLE: People to see, places to go. I've heard it all before.
PERI: It doesn't mean your father isn't interested in what you do. Look, Kyle, I... I know it's hard for you, your dad having a new girlfriend, but I'm a part of Mike's life now, and yours. Can't we try to get along?
KYLE: You really think you're going to be with him forever? Happy ever after?
PERI: I... I hope so.
KYLE: So did Mum.
PERI: Kyle, wait!
HAYTON: Stop. Play.
HAYTON: [OC] Still unsure as to the precise nature of the samplified but initial test...
HAYTON: Stop. Fast forward five minutes, then play.
HAYTON: [OC] Time alone will tell. My experiments continue tomorrow. Science Officer Hayton signing off.
HAYTON: Stop. Record. Log continues. The latest samples of bio-tissue have all demonstrated potential, but none survived long enough under lab conditions to evaluate them fully. Further living samples will be required to...
TAKOL: Professor, we have to talk.
HAYTON: End recording. Don't you ever knock, Major?
TAKOL: Not in my own base, no. Any progress? High Command expects results, and I'd like to give them something sooner rather than later.
HAYTON: Wouldn't you prefer to give them something finished rather than incomplete?
TAKOL: Finished? Then you're getting close?
HAYTON: I am, but I need more samples. Where's Ukarme got to?
TAKOL: He's bringing in some stranger he shot. Apparently the man was babbling something about a doctor.
HAYTON: A doctor, eh? Intriguing. Who do you think he is, Major? Military or mercenary?
TAKOL: We'll soon find out. Come, I need you to bring him round.
ANDREE: Lunch, your Highness?
ERIMEM: Thank you, Andree. I asked First Minister Malarou to join me but he appears to be otherwise engaged. Have his meal sent to him wherever he is.
ANDREE: As you command.
MALAROU: (approaching) My Queen?
ERIMEM: (laughs) Wait, Andree. It seems I am to be graced with his presence after all. Set his food down.
ANDREE: Your Highness.
MALAROU: My Queen. Forgive this lamentable tardiness. I was deep in discussion with one of my aides on the... the matter we were conversing upon this morning.
ERIMEM: Kharto, you mean?
MALAROU: Your Highness, perhaps we'd better discuss this another time somewhere more... private?
ERIMEM: Thank you, Andree. You may leave us.
ANDREE: My Queen.
ERIMEM: Really, Malarou. Andree has been my faithful servant for years.
MALAROU: Nevertheless, one cannot be too careful.
ERIMEM: You see plots and treachery everywhere. Now, let's eat while you tell me your news. Mmm, this looks delicious.
MALAROU: My Queen, wait. The food taster, please.
ERIMEM: Malarou, your concern for my health is touching, but I flatter myself I Know Kharto. He's a troublemaker, not a killer.
MALAROU: Just let the food taster do his job, my Queen.
ERIMEM: Oh, very well. But do it quickly. I should like to eat my lunch while it's still vaguely hot. (claps hands.) Food tasters. I know we should respect our cultural traditions, but this is the twenty fifth century. I doubt anyone has been poisoned since the time of the Pharaohs.
MALAROU: And that is precisely why someone like Kharto might try it now. To surprise us.
ERIMEM: I think you overestimate his cunning. He's the...
ERIMEM: Malarou, do something. He's dying!
MALAROU: Guards! Guards! Fetch the medi-kit, quickly.
HAYTON: Med-scan complete.
TAKOL: Well, Hayton? How is he?
HAYTON: Respiration normal. Pulse rate elevated but within acceptable limits. Well, well. Two hearts.
TAKOL: Two hearts? A cybernetic?
HAYTON: No, no, no. He may not be human, but he is humanoid. Alien, I'd say. It may perhaps explain how he survived so long outside without an environment suit.
TAKOL: Can you bring him round?
HAYTON: With the right equipment, the right funding and enough time, I can do pretty much anything.
TAKOL: (sighs) Here we go again. The ego has landed.
HAYTON: Oh, I know soldiers like to keep things simple. Ready, aim, fire. But science is a little more sophisticated.
TAKOL: You know, you're not the only expert in your field. Maybe I should get myself a new genius.
HAYTON: If you're thinking of Harvard Steel, forget it. He's out in the Zenori System on a long-term bio- energy project. Besides, his methods are questionable to say the least.
TAKOL: Maybe, but he gets results.
HAYTON: Listen Major, if I was allowed to conduct this research along the outlined...
DOCTOR: I'm sorry. Would you mind lowering your voices?
TAKOL: Oh. It seems your patient has recovered without further intervention from you.
DOCTOR: I don't suppose there's any chance of a cup of tea? Stun guns always leave a dry taste in my mouth.
TAKOL: We're fresh out of Darjeeling. Sorry.
DOCTOR: Pity. Well then, I wonder if you'd mind answering a few questions.
TAKOL: When you've answered mine. First off, who are you and where did you come from?
DOCTOR: There's a happy coincidence. Those are two of my questions too, along with where am I?
TAKOL: You don't know where you are?
DOCTOR: I seem to be having some problems with my memory.
HAYTON: Hardly surprising. I'm frankly amazed you have any memory at all. Any longer out there in that jungle, and it would have been destroyed for good.
TAKOL: Hayton.
DOCTOR: Really? I'm the Doctor, by the way.
HAYTON: Professor Darius Hayton at your service, and this is...
TAKOL: I am Major Takol of the Earth Empire Space Marines, Commander of this mission. Assuming the caves where we found you were only a temporary address, where exactly are you from, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Oh, here and there. I'm a traveller. At least, I think so. I journey with... Peri and Erimem. Please, Major, my travelling companions, two young ladies, they must be out there in the jungle.
HAYTON: If they stayed in the caves there may be a chance. Major?
TAKOL: Of course. I'll dispatch Ukarme right away.
DOCTOR: Ukarme?
HAYTON: The soldier who shot you.
DOCTOR: Ah. I hope he's as fast on his feet as he is with his gun.
ERIMEM: Enter.
MALAROU: You summoned me, your Highness?
ERIMEM: Yes, Malarou. Have you found the people responsible for the attempt on my life?
MALAROU: We have made a number of arrests. Forensic tests are being conducted now.
ERIMEM: I want to be told as soon as the results are in.
MALAROU: Of course, my Queen. I, er...
ERIMEM: Is there something else?
MALAROU: Er, Kharto.
ERIMEM: What of him?
MALAROU: He was staying at one of the houses that we raided. We couldn't ignore his presence at what was Clearly a base of rebel activities, so we, er, arrested him.
ERIMEM: Was that wise? His arrest could be the spark the insurgents need.
MALAROU: As I said, we couldn't very easily arrest the others and let Kharto go free, now, could we?
ERIMEM: That is precisely what you should have done. His supporters would have wondered why he had been spared. They would have suspected him of having done a deal with us, selling them out in order to save his own miserable skin. It might not be too late. Fetch Kharto to me. I need to speak to him face to face.
MALAROU: My Queen, I strongly advise against taking such a...
ERIMEM: Make the arrangements.
MALAROU: As you command.
ERIMEM: One thing I learned from my old friend the Doctor. Never miss an opportunity to look your opponent in the eyes.
MALAROU: The Doctor again. Is there no end to his genius. It seems he has a pearl of wisdom for every occasion.
ERIMEM: Do not joke about the Doctor. He was... is a very good friend.
MALAROU: I did not mean to mock. But if he is such a good friend to you, why did he leave you?
ERIMEM: He didn't. I left him. I think.
TAKOL: You think, Hayton? I need some certainty here. Is this Doctor telling the truth?
HAYTON: Well, he appears to be. He had no idea where he was. Think about it, Takol. If he knew anything about this planet he wouldn't have been out in the jungle unprotected, would he?
TAKOL: It might have been a ploy, a ruse to allay suspicion and gain entry to this base.
HAYTON: Not everyone has a twisted mind like yours. He'd have to be a fool or a madman to take a risk like that.
TAKOL: You said he was an alien. Perhaps he has a means to survive out there.
HAYTON: Perhaps I should cut him up and find out how he ticks.
TAKOL: Perhaps.
HAYTON: I was joking.
TAKOL: I wasn't. I don't trust him. If he finds out about what's going on here...
DOCTOR: Ah! There you are. (door closes) I thought I heard voices.
TAKOL: You recovered quickly.
DOCTOR: Yes, I've got pretty good recuperative powers for a man of my age. Any news on my companions?
TAKOL: Nothing yet. Ukarme is still searching for them. We'll let you know the moment we hear anything.
DOCTOR: Thank you. This is a very impressive base, Major. I'd love to take a look around.
TAKOL: I bet you would.
HAYTON: Oh, I'd be only too happy to give you the grand tour. With your permission, Major, naturally.
TAKOL: Granted.
DOCTOR: Most kind. I hope I'm not putting you out.
HAYTON: Not at all. This way, Doctor.
DOCTOR: What did you say this planet was called?
HAYTON: Oh, it doesn't have a name. It's just listed as YT45.
DOCTOR: So what brings a combined military and scientific mission to planet YT45?
HAYTON: You ask a lot of questions, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I find it helps get answers.
TAKOL: Remember, Doctor, curiosity killed the cat.
ERIMEM: Andree, if you must stay with me, kindly stand still.
ANDREE: I'm sorry, my Queen, but I fear for your safety. Kharto would kill you given the chance.
ERIMEM: A chance he will be denied, Andree. I am well-guarded as you can see. But I am touched by your concern. Thank you.
ANDREE: I have served you all my life, my Queen, ever since I could first walk.
ERIMEM: You have indeed been a faithful companion, Andree, one in whom I have... Wait a minute. That cannot be right.
ANDREE: Your Highness?
ERIMEM: You can't have served me since you were a child. That would be, what, twenty years ago.
ANDREE: You've ruled New Cairo since the colony was founded over twenty five years ago.
ERIMEM: That's not possible.
HAYTON: Ta-da! The highlight of the tour - my laboratory.
DOCTOR: Very impressive.
HAYTON: You're too kind, Doctor. Like the rest of the base, it's just stock pre-fab. But I've tried to personalise it with my own clutter.
DOCTOR: It looks a little less temporary than the other units.
HAYTON: Ah well, that's the military mind-set for you. In and out quick as you can then onto the next mission...
DOCTOR: So what exactly is the mission this time?
HAYTON: Top secret, I'm afraid.
DOCTOR: And who's this fellow? A native?
HAYTON: Indeed. This planet's answer to a primate. We call them Jekylls.
DOCTOR: Jekylls?
HAYTON: Let's just say they have a split personality.
DOCTOR: Well, this one seems friendly enough. Looks as bit like an oversized lemur, don't you.
HAYTON: Oh, he is friendly, by day. But come nightfall it's a different matter. Observe those incisors, Doctor. Lethal. And he's strong too. Oh, he could rend you limb from limb if he had a mind to.
DOCTOR: Fascinating. But he's not your main interest here, is he?
HAYTON: What makes you say that?
DOCTOR: All these plants. I suspect you of being a closet botanist.
HAYTON: Ah! My secret is out.
DOCTOR: Now, let's see. A Methuselan poppy, Gavinci's strangle-weed. Very nasty. And this is... Kemsel moss?
HAYTON: I'm impressed. It's a pleasure to meet a fellow aficionado.
DOCTOR: Oh, Peri's the expert. I'm merely an enthusiastic amateur. Peri. Wait, I remember now. Peri and I were looking at some flowers. Purple ones like on the plants in this terrarium.
HAYTON: Kyropites.
DOCTOR: Kyropites? Is that what they're called? I've never seen anything like them before.
HAYTON: No one has.
DOCTOR: They're the real reason you're here, aren't they?
HAYTON: What makes you think that?
DOCTOR: Interesting. You're not denying it. Now, I wonder. Could there be some kind of connection between these plants and what happened to me out in the jungle? My memory loss?
HAYTON: That's quite a leap, Doctor.
DOCTOR: But you don't sound very surprised by it. So not a leap in the dark, then.
HAYTON: The kyropites do seem to have an unpleasant effect on people. And on the Jekylls too.
DOCTOR: Memory loss?
HAYTON: That's part of it, yes. If you'd been out there much longer it would have been far worse.
DOCTOR: As in fatal?
HAYTON: I'm afraid so. A routine survey mission landed here six months ago. At first all their data was being fast-beamed home, everything normal, and then... nothing.
DOCTOR: The survey team started dying?
HAYTON: Every last one of them.
DOCTOR: And yet despite the danger, Major Takol wanted to lead a second mission here.
HAYTON: The military believe that these plants may have potential.
DOCTOR: As a weapon, you mean? Why? What's so special about these kyropites?
HAYTON: I'll show you. Now, observe what happens when I introduce some foreign matter, in this case Heager Worms, to the kyropites in this terrarium. Don't worry, it's sealed.
DOCTOR: Fascinating. Some kind of anaesthetic gas?
HAYTON: Precisely. Oh, don't worry. The worms will make a full recovery, I guarantee it.
DOCTOR: But why anaesthetise your attacker? Why not simply kill him?
HAYTON: They need him alive. They're neurological parasites. They feed telepathically on alpha waves, usually from the local wildlife. They wouldn't get much from these little chaps, of course, but with more advanced species the results can be spectacular.
DOCTOR: The Jekylls, you mean?
HAYTON: It appears they've developed some kind of symbiotic relationship. Far from pacifying the Jekylls, it makes them killers. Friendly by day, deadly at night.
DOCTOR: But why? What purpose would that serve?
HAYTON: It offers protection to the plants. Some creatures are more resistant to the anaesthetic gas than others. The Jekylls make sure that they are removed from the evolutionary tree.
DOCTOR: Unnatural selection.
HAYTON: Whatever you call it, that's what happened to the original survey team. And not just them. We landed here during the planet's night cycle, and lost three of our men the same way.
DOCTOR: Horrible. So those the Jekylls leave alive, the plants send into some kind of coma.
HAYTON: Not a coma exactly. It's more like a deep sleep. The victims are dreaming the whole time, producing plenty of alpha waves to feed the plants. And another thing. It's as if the plants share the dream experience.
DOCTOR: But that's incredible.
HAYTON: Nevertheless, that is what appears to be happening. What did you experience?
DOCTOR: I don't think I succumbed to actual sleep, but I did feel something, a presence in my head.
HAYTON: Do you have any history of telepathy?
DOCTOR: A little.
HAYTON: It's possible that made you less susceptible.
DOCTOR: There's something very odd about al this. Something that doesn't add up. How can you know what happens to the victims? How can you know what goes on in their unconscious minds?
HAYTON: By monitoring their dreams, of course.
DOCTOR: You can do that?
HAYTON: Naturally.
UKARME: Ukarme here. I've found some tracks.
TAKOL: [OC]: Follow them. And be careful, Ukarme. I've already lost enough members of this expedition.
UKARME: I didn't Know you cared, Major.
TAKOL: [OC]:] don't. I just don't want to blot my career record by adding to the numbers of deaths under my command column.
UKARME: I'm reassured by your concern. Wait. Major, there's something here. It's a woman.
TAKOL: [OC]: What state is she in?
UKARME: Alive, and in deep sleep. No sign of the other one.
TAKOL: [OC]: Get her loaded on the drone and back here right away. Full decontamination protocols for both of you.
UKARME: Yes, sir.
DOCTOR: You're seriously telling me that you have a machine capable of accessing a person's dreams?
HAYTON: Yes.
DOCTOR: I didn't realise human research in these fields was so advanced.
HAYTON: It's not. We had help.
DOCTOR: I see. Your machine is based on alien technology.
HAYTON: We traded it from the Dreamweavers of the Goyana System. Oh, excuse me. Hayton here?
TAKOL: [OC]: Professor, tell the Doctor that Ukarme's found one of his friends.
DOCTOR: One? But they were together.
TAKOL: [OC]: Sorry, he just found one. A dark-skinned girl.
MALAROU: The prisoner, your Highness.
KHARTO: My noble and just Queen. Kharto greets you, and humbly prostrates himself before your ineffable Majesty.
ERIMEM: Thank you, Malarou. You may leave us.
MALAROU: But my Queen, Kharto is...
ERIMEM: Handcuffed and unarmed. Now, take your guards and leave us.
MALAROU: As you command.
ERIMEM: You too, Andree.
ANDREE: I would rather stay with my Queen.
ERIMEM: So be it. Get up, Kharto. Your fervent loyalty is impressing no one.
KHARTO: As you wish, my most honourable Queen.
ERIMEM: And you can stop that too. If you must call me anything, let it be Erimem. Now, I understand you have some issues with the way things are run around here.
KHARTO: Some issues? You could say that. I think the future of this entire colony is in jeopardy.
DOCTOR: Ukarme. Nice to see you again.
UKARME: Doctor, Professor, she's over here.
DOCTOR: Erimem. Was she like this when you found her?
UKARME: Yes. In a deep sleep, surrounded by those plants. Are we to wake her?
HAYTON: Absolutely not. That would be a very dangerous to do. Any attempt at sudden withdrawal from the
HAYTON: dream state could cause extensive cerebral damage.
UKARME: I don't understand.
DOCTOR: Neither do I. Explain, Hayton. Those Heager Worms made a full recovery with no ill effects.
HAYTON: That's because we revived them almost immediately. The dreams these plants initiate are complex neurological fantasies. They feel completely real. In some respects, they are real. And the longer you're under, the harder it is to tear the mind away from that reality. Your friend here looks to be at stage two.
DOCTOR: Stage two?
HAYTON: Stage one lasts only for the first few hours. There's no dreaming, just plant-induced sleep. I believe that the plant uses this time to access the victim's memories and construct a fantasy world to entrap their minds.
DOCTOR: And stage two is when the dream world has been created, and the victim believes themselves to be awake in this fantasy.
HAYTON: Correct. Stage three is the penultimate stage. The plant begins to physically bond with the victim, initiating the process of absorption.
UKARME: And stage four?
HAYTON: Death.
ERIMEM: So, Kharto, you would do things differently, I take it?
KHARTO: I would. First off, stop living in the past. All these reminders of Ancient Egypt. What's the point?
ERIMEM: To remember where we came from.
KHARTO: It's the twenty fifth century. The Pyramids would be dust by now had they not been encased in plastic.
ERIMEM: But if we forget our past we lose all sense of who we are.
KHARTO: Who are we, then? Pale imitations of our ancient ancestors. Is that really why you came here in the first place? Is it?
ERIMEM: I... I don't know.
KHARTO: You don't know?
ERIMEM: I can't seem to remember. A temporary amnesia, nothing more. What I do know for sure is that it is I and not you who leads this colony.
KHARTO: Yet you cannot tell me by what right. You cannot even remember how you came to be here. No wonder the colony is on the brink of disaster.
ERIMEM: Andree! What on Earth are you doing? You... you've killed him.
ANDREE: And you, my Queen, will be next.
DOCTOR: Erimem. Erimem, can you hear me?
HAYTON: Don't, Doctor. You mustn't.
DOCTOR: But if we can just get her to wake up... Surely there are stimulants you can use.
HAYTON: Haven't you been listening to what I've been saying? These are more than dreams, they're complex controlled simulacrums of real life. Look at the med-schematics. Wild variations in her heartbeat, irregular breathing patterns, massive alpha wave activity. That's not normal for a sleeping person. As far as she's concerned, her dreamscape is real.
DOCTOR: But what if something happened to her in the dream world? If she fell off a cliff, drowned?
HAYTON: If she dies in the dream, she will die here in the lab too.
ERIMEM: Andree, think about it. My death will achieve nothing. You'll be dead before you can leave the building. Another martyr to the cause like poor Kharto here.
ANDREE: I care nothing for the cause. Last year when Kharto first began to speak out, there was a rally, an open meeting of people who were unhappy about your rule.
ERIMEM: I do not remember.
ANDREE: The Royal Guard arrived to break up the meeting, but that wasn't enough for you. You wanted to make an example of the malcontents. You ordered the guards to start firing into the crowd.
ERIMEM: No, I would never...
ANDREE: They gunned down forty men and women, my parents included.
ERIMEM: I refuse to believe it.
ANDREE: They showed no mercy, and neither will I. I failed in my first attempt, to poison you.
ERIMEM: The food taster. You mean that was you?
ANDREE: This time you will not be so lucky. Goodbye, your Majesty.
ERIMEM: No. Andree, please!

elements.text: [Part Two]
[TV]: Oh Guido, we've gone well beyond that kind of formality, you and I. You're not just some guy who works at the City and District Hospital, you're a... a friend.
[TV]: A friend?
[TV]: Don't tell me you don't like the idea?
Door opens.
(TV) No, no, it isn't that...
I was beginning to worry about you.
Oh, sorry.
Door closes.
Got held up at the office.
Held down, you mean, by some leggy blonde.
Ha, ha, ha, I wish. Joke. And don't pout like that. You know I find it wildly erotic.
Come here and say that.
They kiss. The TV is turned off.
Is everything all right? Kyle hasn't laid into you again?
No, no, nothing like that.
Oh, it's all a bit much for him. It was bad enough when I started dating again after Rachel left, but he accepted that... eventually, and he'll accept you too in time.
I hope so.
Trust me. Everything's going to be all right, as long as we have each other, eh?
Mmm.
They kiss.
Now, what's for dinner?
Oh.
Andree? Please, Andree, breathe.
I... despised you.
Why didn't you set it on stun, you foo!!
Oh, I am sorry, your Highness. She was about to kill you. I didn't have time to stop and think.
Kharto coughs.
Kharto. He's alive! Quick, Malarou, fetch the medics.
But my Queen, he is our enemy.
He is an opponent, not an enemy. And if this colony is to survive, we need him alive. Dead, he'll be a martyr to fanatics. Now, get those medics!
How is she?
She seems stable for now. Classic stage two.
There must be something we can do to help her.
The Doctor's right, Professor. Isn't there anything we can do?
Well, there is one possibility but it's totally untested.
What is it?
Tell me. Anything is better than watching Erimem die in slow stages.
I've been experimenting on the plants, trying to extract the agent that causes these dreams.
To develop an antidote?
Not exactly.
Then what?
I think I can use it to put someone - you, Doctor - into a similar state of unconsciousness.
What would be the point of that?

The point, Ukarme, is that I can then use the Dream Scanner to harmonise the alpha waves generated in the Doctor's hypothalamus with those of his companion here. Then the plant extract should boost his natural telepathic abilities, allowing him to enter Erimem's dreamscape.
But that's impossible.
No. Just highly improbable. Lucid dreaming. You think it'll work?
There's a chance. If you can persuade her that the reality she perceives is false, she may wake up safely.
Then what are we waiting for? Let's get Erimem to your laboratory.
It will be risky. Much of this is just theory and speculation. I've not yet had the opportunity to test out these ideas.
Then let me be your guinea pig. And Ukarme?
Yes, Doctor.
Find my other companion. Find Peri.
Knocking on door.
Kyle?
[OC]: What?
Kyle.
[OC]: What?
Can I come in?
[TV OC]: Previously on Love MD.
[OC]: No.
Kyle, you need to get dressed and go to school.
[OC]: Can't. I've got a headache.
Then take something and get back to sleep. Don't lie around watching trash on the TV.
[OC]: Thanks for the sympathy. I'll text you when I die.
(sigh) As you like to say, whatever.
Right, that's both of you hooked up to the monitors. Sorry about the audience, by the way.
He's probably excited to see someone else being operated on.
Door opens.
What the hell's going on here? Ukarme muttered something to me about an experiment.
Door closes.
The Doctor's volunteered to test the plant extract I told you about.
Is that wise?
I need to know if this stuff works. Arm please, Doctor.
And I need to help my friend before it's too late.
This shouldn't hurt.
Ow!
You'll feel very fatigued, very quickly. Can you count backwards from ten for me, please?
Certainly. Ten, nine, eight... er, six.
He's gone.
Where?
Into dreamland.
The outer walls of the palace have been breached, your Highness.
What of Kharto? Can he not speak to the rebels, delay them?
Alas, my Queen, he is currently unconscious in his cell.
Then it is over. The rebellion has succeeded.
No. While you are free there is hope.
But I am not free, am I? I am trapped.
Then be trapped on your own terms. You are aware of the Panic Room that was constructed in your quarters?
Panic Room?
It is just a precaution. You will be safe there while we rally our troops and eject the rebels.
And if you fail?
The Panic Room has communications. You can negotiate or call to off-worlders for aid. Either way you will be safe.
While my country crumbles around me.
Report, Ukarme.
[OC]: Harvesting initiated, Major, as requested.
Excellent. The shuttle will be down before nightfall. Make sure we have enough samples to fill the hold. Takol out.
I thought he was supposed to be looking for the Doctor's other companion.
I have other priorities. Yes, Ukarme, what is it?
[OC]:The safety override has cut in. Forward scan threw up a foreign body, Major, and the harvester went into emergency shutdown. I'm checking it out now.
Can't you just harvest it along with the plants? We don't have time for this.
[OC]: Afraid not, sir. The safety protocols won't allow it in case the machine gets damaged. I could always... Wait! Major, it's the other woman, half-buried in the plants.
Oh. What condition is she in, Ukarme?
[OC]: It's - hard to tell where she ends and the plants begin.
Bring her in. I need to see this.
[OC]: I'll have to cut her free first.
No. Dig her up. Use the harvester's forward scoop. I want the plant that's consuming her too. And hurry. Hayton out. This could be the breakthrough we need.
Oh, now what?
The machine's monitoring the Doctor's delta waves. That signal means he's now in synch with his friend here. He's in.
The Panic Room, your Highness.
Ironic, isn't it? Knharto was complaining that we are too obsessed with the past, and here is a sealed chamber that could have graced one of the Pyramids. I hope it is not destined to become my tomb.
I will not abandon you, my Queen.
But if something should happen to you?
There is another way out. A secret door on the far wall that leads to an escape tunnel. That will take you to a safe house. The details are here in this file.
And how do I stay in contact with you? How will I know what is happening?
The screens are patched into the security network. You have full audio and video communications, including off-world.
Right, then. You'd better seal me in before I change my mind. You are certain that this is for the best?
Positive. Farewell, my Queen. May the Gods protect you.
Door closes.
(distorted) Hello. I wonder whether you can... (normal)... help me.
Oh! Who are you, and how did you get into the Inner Palace?
I'm the Doctor, and I've just arrived.
No space craft have landed today.
It's all a bit mysterious, I admit, but I assure you I pose no threat to you or your world. Mister...?
I am First Minister Malarou of the colony New Cairo on the planet Kandoor.
New Cairo, eh? That explains the ancient Egyptian decor. What on Earth has Erimem got going on in her subconscious to come up with something like this?
Security alert. Ra sector.
Now, there's no need for that. I'm just here for a quick word with Erimem. Is she through there?
Stand back. No one but a rebel would dare speak the Queen's name with such a lack of respect.
Queen? Of course, I should have guessed. It's Queen Erimem,, is it? Well, it's her dream, I suppose.
Guards, seize him and put him in the cells with his friend Kharto. Let's see if that jogs his memory at all.
It's not my memory that needs jogging. Now, listen, Minister Malarou, I need to see Queen Erimem urgently. It's a matter of life and death.

I'm sure it is, but I'm afraid we're not so accommodating to assassins round here. The Queen is safe within the heart of this Palace, and there she will stay until your pathetic rebellion is crushed. Take him away.
(receding) You don't understand. It's not part of any rebellion, it's vitally important that I speak to the Queen. Listen to me!
Knocking on door.
Kyle, honey?
[YV OC]: Sorry, Doctor Love.
I made you some sandwiches.
Door opens.
[OC]: I thought we agreed you were going to call me Carla.
Ta-da! Sandwiches.
[TV]: Guido, please.
Oh, come on, Kyle.
[TV]: What's wrong?
[TV]: I... can't tell you.
Kyle?
[OC]: You're hiding something.
Oh no.
[TV]: Why don't you just tell me?
Kyle, can you hear me, honey? I'm getting help. Oh Jeez, you're burning up.
[OC]: Emergency services. Which service do you require?
Oh yes. Ambulance. I need an ambulance. My stepson's unconscious.
Here she is, Professor, what's left of her.
Good work, Ukarme.
Door closes.
Remarkable. The kyropites are bonding with her skin, keeping her alive while simultaneously
killing her.
What's that?
Increased brainwave activity. Her heartbeat's racing too. She must be experiencing something traumatic in her dream.
I never realised dreams could affect our bodies to this extent.
The human brain is a very powerful thing, Ukarme. The relationship between mind and body is still very much a mystery.
Not to these plants.
You're not as stupid as you look, are you?
Thanks for the vote of confidence, Professor.
Sorry. I meant no offence. I just have a very dim view of the military mind.
Door opens.
Well Professor, how's the human vegetable?
(sotto) And with good reason.
Door closes.
Sorry?

Nothing, Major. Just a little joke between Ukarme and myself. The human vegetable, as you put it, is well into stage three. The tendrils have already begun to bond to the skin. Over the next twenty four hours the cells in the epidermis will begin to mutate.
And then?
Who knows? Perhaps she'll become some kind of human-plant hybrid. Once we get her to the med lab and I run some tests I'll be able to tell you more.
How are the Doctor and the other girl?
No change. A brief peak in his alpha waves a while ago, but nothing since.
Ukarme, after you've finished being the Professor's porter, get back to monitoring the harvesters. I want that ship full of these plants and in orbit as soon as possible.
Yes, Major.
Nothing must delay the harvest. Not even you, Doctor.
Bang.
No good. Won't budge.
You surprise me. I take it this is your first experience of being in a prison cell.
Not at all. I've escaped from more cells than you've had hot dinners.
Really.
My old friend Harry Houdini taught me a thing or two about picking locks. No box can hold me, he always said, and it worked a treat for him. Until he died, of course.
(laughs) A fine mentor he was, my friend.
You have a point. I'm the Doctor, by the way, and you are...?
My name is Kharto.
Kharto? Malarou mentioned you. I take it you're something to do with the rebellion?
I'm supposed to be its leader. (laughs) Not much use, am I, banged up in here?
Let's see if we can do something about that.
You're serious?
Most of the time. Let's have a look at this door. Hmm. So tell me, what's this revolt all about?
Our Queen is living in the past, trying to make this colony some kind of living museum, a recreation of our ancient home on Earth.
And that's a bad thing?
It's nearly three millennia since the time of the Pharaohs. We're hundreds of light years away from Earth. We need to live in the here and now, not some dream of times past.
But Erimem prefers this dream. Interesting.
You speak of her as if you know her.

Indeed I do. And I need to speak to her urgently. If only I can open this door. I'm not sure where she is, but I have my suspicions. Malarou mentioned something about her being safe in the heart of the palace.
The Panic Room.
The Panic Room? You know about it?
(laughs) My brother built it. Get me out of this cell, Doctor, and I can get you into that room in no time. I too would like to speak to Queen Erimem. We have unfinished business, she and I.
Paging Doctor Paris. Paging Doctor Paris.
Come on, come on, pick up. Ah. Darling, it's me. I'm...
[OC]: Hi. Neither Mike, Kyle or Peri are in right now, so leave a message at the sound of the tone.
beep!

Mike, where the hell are you? The office said you'd gone out, but your mobile's switched off, and you're not at home either. Now, don't panic, but you need to get to the hospital at once. Saint Peter's. It's Kyle. He's got meningitis. We think he's going to be okay, but...
Beep!
Damn!
Flanagan please come to Reception. Doctor Flanagan please come...
No obvious weakness in that wall either. So, Kharto, how do you fit into Erimem's world? What purpose do you serve in it, I wonder?
Erimem's world? Ha! If you're suggesting she created this colony all by herself you are sadly mistaken. There were thousands of colony ships, twelve great founders.
Really? And just who were they, these great founders? What are their names? When did their colony ships arrive? Where are they from?
They were... I don't know. What's wrong with me, Doctor? Why can't I remember anything?
It's a little complicated to explain. Right now though I think we should concentrate on getting this door open.
Dream on, my friend. You'll never open that door.
Dream on. Of course. If this is a dreamscape, I can manipulate it. If I can just concentrate.
Clunk, creak.
How did you do that?
Mind over matter. Come on.
(coughs) Dad?
Kyle? You're awake. I'll fetch the nurse.
Wait. Where's Dad?
He's on his way, honey.
I'm half dead and he's... on his way?
I promise you. He'll be here very soon.
I felt so bad, and you just told me to take some pills.
I made a mistake. I'm... I'm sorry, Kyle. Kyle? Okay, honey. You can hear my apologies later. For now, sleep well and sweet dreams.
Malarou? Come in please, Malarou, this is Erimem calling. Oh, where has he got to?
Door unlocked.
Who's there? Malarou, is that you?
No, Erimem, it's me. The Doctor.
Doctor? But you... This can't be happening. This is some kind of trick. You changed, you... you left me.
Erimem, please, you have to listen to me. This colony, this world, none of it's real. It's an illusion. A dream.
Are you mad? Why would I dream about rebels, and food tasters dying and servants betraying me?
Your dream is being directed, controlled by parasitic plants we encountered on an alien world.
Stop it, Doctor, you're frightening me.
Doctor, someone's coming up the passageway. Guards, I think. I'll hold them off as long as I can.
Thank you, Kharto. We won't be long.
Kharto? But he was locked up. What's going on, Doctor?
This world, it doesn't make sense. It's a mishmash of your old home on Earth and the kinds of frontier worlds you visited with me in the Tardis.
Oh, this is the Terran colony New Cairo on the planet Kandoor, part of the Hyran System.
There is no such colony, never was, never will be. This is all an illusion and you have to reject it.
Laser guns.
[OC]: Keep back, both of you.

Think about it, Erimem. Where did Kharto get that gun from? He wasn't carrying it when he came in just now. Why is it always the same two guards who appear? Where is everyone else in this great colony?
I... I need to speak to Malarou. He'll know the truth.
Malarou doesn't exist. You have to wake up, Erimem. You have to remember. We landed on a jungle planet - you, me and Peri - and we all fell victim to these parasitical telepathic plants.
But Peri left us, ages ago.
[OC]: Doctor, I can't hold them off. They... argh!
Where? Tell me where and how Peri left.
I... I can't remember.
Because it never happened. It's a detail your subconscious never bothered to establish, like the
details about how this colony works or how it was founded.
Oh, this is all madness.
And the madness stops now.
First Minister Malarou.
Your Highness, this alien is dangerous. He's playing with your mind, but you must be strong. Reject him, ignore his lies. You must accept this reality.
Must accept this reality? What you know of different realities, Malarou?
Queen Erimem, I merely wish to protect you from this warlock. He has cast a spell on you.
Have you cast a spell on me, Doctor? How else can you be in my dream but by magic?
Magic? Nonsense. I'm using some advanced alien technology.
That sounds like the Doctor I remember.
I am the Doctor you remember. Now Erimem, close your eyes and listen to me. You are not in this room. This room does not exist. You are in a medical bed in a lab.
No, my Queen. Don't listen to him. The rebellion is crushed. New Cairo is
There is an air purifier operating in the room. Can you hear it? Feel the air as it passes over your sleeping body.
(fading) Stay with us. Help us build a new world.
You're asleep, that's all. Now it's time to wake up.
Erimem?
She seems to be coming out of it now, Doctor. Welcome back, by the way. And well done.
Thank you, Ukarme. Where's Hayton?
The Professor had to leave. He went to the med lab.
Doctor?
I'm here, Erimem. How are you feeling?
Like I've been asleep for ages. I had the strangest dream. It was so vivid. Aman called Malarou was there, and so were you. Where are we?
In a laboratory on the jungle planet YT45.
And where is Peri?
I can answer that one. I found her, Doctor. She's alive. That's why the Professor dashed off. He has her in the med lab now.
Excellent. Good work, Ukarme. Can you keep an eye on Erimem for me?
Of course.
Then I'll go and see Hayton. He's got some explaining to do.
Consultant to Paediatrics, please. Consultant to Paediatrics.
Ringing tone.

Come on, Ally. What's the point of having a best friend if they don't pick up the damn phone? Oh, great. First my boyfriend, now my best friend. Who's going to be next to ignore my call, my mother? Well, when the going gets tough, the tough get going. Home time.
Look at her. Can you see? Incredible, isn't it?
[OC]: If you like that sort of thing.
My theory is correct. The process of absorption leads to a mutation in the DNA structure. Changes are happening at a chemical level in the victim's brain.
[OC]: Giving us a means to unlock telepathic ability in humans.
It certainly looks that way.
[OC]: I need to report this to High Command. Good work, Hayton.
My pleasure. Right then, my dear, let's open you up and see exactly what's going on, shall we?
Door opens
Professor. Would you mind putting that laser cutter down and moving away from your patient?
Doctor. It worked, then. Is Erimem awake?
Never mind Erimem, it's Peri I'm concerned with at the moment.
Peri? Oh, you mean the hybrid here. I'm sorry. I know she was your friend, but there's nothing that can be done for her now.
How can you be so sure?
Because she's already well into stage three. She won't die in vain, though. She can still be useful to us, as a Subject.
Leave her alone, Hayton. I'm warning you.
I'm sorry, Doctor. I cannot allow you to stand in the way of scientific advancement because of some trivial emotional attachment you may harbour.
Here. Have some water.
Thank you. Ukarme, is it?
Yes. I was the one who found you out in the jungle, and brought you back here.
Then I am indebted to you.
Oh, I'm just glad to see you up and about. How are you feeling?
Very strange. I'm not entirely convinced that this is not a dream too.
What was it like, when you were in the dream place?
It felt... (sighs)... real.
You had no idea that you were dreaming?
Not really. Everything seemed to make sense at the time. I was the ruler of a space colony.
(laughs) Really? You must have a very well-developed ego.
(laughs) You should have seen me back home.
Little Miss Absolute Ruler.
(laughs) You have no idea.
Walking on gravel, unlocking a door.
Mike? I'm home, honey. Where have you been? I was beginning to panic until I saw your car out front. Mike? Mike? Is that you?
Door opens. Ally laughing.
Mike? Ally?
Oh my God. Peri.
I... I can explain.
What's to explain? I've just found my boyfriend in my bedroom with my best friend. Doesn't get much clearer than that.
No, wait, please, just hear me out.
I don't want to. Just leave me alone!
Peri? Peri?
It was so real, you could taste it. More vivid than anything I've ever dreamt before.
And how do you feel now? Does your dream seem less real?
Not at the moment. Maybe it will in time. Why are you so interested? I thought you were a soldier, not a scientist.
Maybe there is more to me than just this uniform.
I'm sorry, Ukarme, that was rude of me. I don't know you at all. I'd no right to make assumptions.
It is I who should apologise to you. I haven't been entirely honest with you.
Oh, I should have known. You were too polite for a soldier. Well, are you going to kill me or make me your prisoner?
Is that what this is all about? Scientific advancement?
Why else would I be risking my life in this hell-hole? It's hardly a top vacation spot.
So that's why you had samples of the plant extract ready to hand. You're planning to sell it on the open market.

The mind controlling properties alone make it commercially viable, but thanks to your friend here, I may also be able to isolate the chemical that stimulates telepathic ability. Think of the possible markets for a drug like that.
I cannot allow it.
And who are you to stop me?
I'm the Doctor.
Ah, of course! You're FDA, aren't you?
FDA?

Don't play dumb. The Federation Drugs Administration. I knew you pen-pushing bureaucrats would eventually catch up with me. Well, you can tell your bosses they can forget it. I'll bypass their ridiculously long and expensive drugs trials and make a fortune before they can do a thing about it.
And what about the military who funded this mission? How are they going to feel about you taking this for your own?
Takol's a fool, and so are High Command.
Peri, come back! It's not how it looks!
Leave me alone. How could you do that to me? To your son!
Peri, look out!
Car horn blares. Peri screams, smack, thud.

CARLA: [TV]: Oh Guido, we've gone well beyond that kind of formality, you and I. You're not just some guy who works at the City and District Hospital, you're a... a friend.
GUIDO: [TV]: A friend?
CARLA: [TV]: Don't tell me you don't like the idea?
GUIDO: (TV) No, no, it isn't that...
PERI: I was beginning to worry about you.
MIKE: Oh, sorry.
MIKE: Got held up at the office.
PERI: Held down, you mean, by some leggy blonde.
MIKE: Ha, ha, ha, I wish. Joke. And don't pout like that. You know I find it wildly erotic.
PERI: Come here and say that.
MIKE: Is everything all right? Kyle hasn't laid into you again?
PERI: No, no, nothing like that.
MIKE: Oh, it's all a bit much for him. It was bad enough when I started dating again after Rachel left, but he accepted that... eventually, and he'll accept you too in time.
PERI: I hope so.
MIKE: Trust me. Everything's going to be all right, as long as we have each other, eh?
PERI: Mmm.

PERI: Oh.
ERIMEM: Andree? Please, Andree, breathe.

ERIMEM: Kharto. He's alive! Quick, Malarou, fetch the medics.
MALAROU: But my Queen, he is our enemy.
ERIMEM: He is an opponent, not an enemy. And if this colony is to survive, we need him alive. Dead, he'll be a martyr to fanatics. Now, get those medics!
DOCTOR: How is she?
HAYTON: She seems stable for now. Classic stage two.
DOCTOR: There must be something we can do to help her.
UKARME: The Doctor's right, Professor. Isn't there anything we can do?
HAYTON: Well, there is one possibility but it's totally untested.
UKARME: What is it?
DOCTOR: Tell me. Anything is better than watching Erimem die in slow stages.
HAYTON: I've been experimenting on the plants, trying to extract the agent that causes these dreams.
DOCTOR: To develop an antidote?
HAYTON: Not exactly.
DOCTOR: Then what?
HAYTON: I think I can use it to put someone - you, Doctor - into a similar state of unconsciousness.
UKARME: What would be the point of that?
HAYTON: The point, Ukarme, is that I can then use the Dream Scanner to harmonise the alpha waves generated in the Doctor's hypothalamus with those of his companion here. Then the plant extract should boost his natural telepathic abilities, allowing him to enter Erimem's dreamscape.
UKARME: But that's impossible.
DOCTOR: No. Just highly improbable. Lucid dreaming. You think it'll work?
HAYTON: There's a chance. If you can persuade her that the reality she perceives is false, she may wake up safely.
DOCTOR: Then what are we waiting for? Let's get Erimem to your laboratory.
HAYTON: It will be risky. Much of this is just theory and speculation. I've not yet had the opportunity to test out these ideas.
DOCTOR: Then let me be your guinea pig. And Ukarme?
UKARME: Yes, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Find my other companion. Find Peri.
PERI: Kyle?
KYLE: [OC]: What?
PERI: Kyle.
KYLE: [OC]: What?
PERI: Can I come in?
ANNOUNCER: [TV OC]: Previously on Love MD.
KYLE: [OC]: No.
PERI: Kyle, you need to get dressed and go to school.
KYLE: [OC]: Can't. I've got a headache.
PERI: Then take something and get back to sleep. Don't lie around watching trash on the TV.
KYLE: [OC]: Thanks for the sympathy. I'll text you when I die.
PERI: (sigh) As you like to say, whatever.
HAYTON: Right, that's both of you hooked up to the monitors. Sorry about the audience, by the way.
DOCTOR: He's probably excited to see someone else being operated on.
TAKOL: What the hell's going on here? Ukarme muttered something to me about an experiment.
HAYTON: The Doctor's volunteered to test the plant extract I told you about.
TAKOL: Is that wise?
HAYTON: I need to know if this stuff works. Arm please, Doctor.
DOCTOR: And I need to help my friend before it's too late.
HAYTON: This shouldn't hurt.
DOCTOR: Ow!
HAYTON: You'll feel very fatigued, very quickly. Can you count backwards from ten for me, please?
DOCTOR: Certainly. Ten, nine, eight... er, six.
HAYTON: He's gone.
TAKOL: Where?
HAYTON: Into dreamland.
MALAROU: The outer walls of the palace have been breached, your Highness.
ERIMEM: What of Kharto? Can he not speak to the rebels, delay them?
MALAROU: Alas, my Queen, he is currently unconscious in his cell.
ERIMEM: Then it is over. The rebellion has succeeded.
MALAROU: No. While you are free there is hope.
ERIMEM: But I am not free, am I? I am trapped.
MALAROU: Then be trapped on your own terms. You are aware of the Panic Room that was constructed in your quarters?
ERIMEM: Panic Room?
MALAROU: It is just a precaution. You will be safe there while we rally our troops and eject the rebels.
ERIMEM: And if you fail?
MALAROU: The Panic Room has communications. You can negotiate or call to off-worlders for aid. Either way you will be safe.
ERIMEM: While my country crumbles around me.
TAKOL: Report, Ukarme.
UKARME: [OC]: Harvesting initiated, Major, as requested.
TAKOL: Excellent. The shuttle will be down before nightfall. Make sure we have enough samples to fill the hold. Takol out.
HAYTON: I thought he was supposed to be looking for the Doctor's other companion.
TAKOL: I have other priorities. Yes, Ukarme, what is it?
UKARME: [OC]:The safety override has cut in. Forward scan threw up a foreign body, Major, and the harvester went into emergency shutdown. I'm checking it out now.
TAKOL: Can't you just harvest it along with the plants? We don't have time for this.
UKARME: [OC]: Afraid not, sir. The safety protocols won't allow it in case the machine gets damaged. I could always... Wait! Major, it's the other woman, half-buried in the plants.
HAYTON: Oh. What condition is she in, Ukarme?
UKARME: [OC]: It's - hard to tell where she ends and the plants begin.
HAYTON: Bring her in. I need to see this.
UKARME: [OC]: I'll have to cut her free first.
HAYTON: No. Dig her up. Use the harvester's forward scoop. I want the plant that's consuming her too. And hurry. Hayton out. This could be the breakthrough we need.
TAKOL: Oh, now what?
HAYTON: The machine's monitoring the Doctor's delta waves. That signal means he's now in synch with his friend here. He's in.
MALAROU: The Panic Room, your Highness.
ERIMEM: Ironic, isn't it? Knharto was complaining that we are too obsessed with the past, and here is a sealed chamber that could have graced one of the Pyramids. I hope it is not destined to become my tomb.
MALAROU: I will not abandon you, my Queen.
ERIMEM: But if something should happen to you?
MALAROU: There is another way out. A secret door on the far wall that leads to an escape tunnel. That will take you to a safe house. The details are here in this file.
ERIMEM: And how do I stay in contact with you? How will I know what is happening?
MALAROU: The screens are patched into the security network. You have full audio and video communications, including off-world.
ERIMEM: Right, then. You'd better seal me in before I change my mind. You are certain that this is for the best?
MALAROU: Positive. Farewell, my Queen. May the Gods protect you.
DOCTOR: (distorted) Hello. I wonder whether you can... (normal)... help me.
MALAROU: Oh! Who are you, and how did you get into the Inner Palace?
DOCTOR: I'm the Doctor, and I've just arrived.

DOCTOR: (receding) You don't understand. It's not part of any rebellion, it's vitally important that I speak to the Queen. Listen to me!

KHARTO: The Panic Room.
DOCTOR: The Panic Room? You know about it?
KHARTO: (laughs) My brother built it. Get me out of this cell, Doctor, and I can get you into that room in no time. I too would like to speak to Queen Erimem. We have unfinished business, she and I.

PERI: Come on, come on, pick up. Ah. Darling, it's me. I'm...

PERI: Damn!

DOCTOR: No obvious weakness in that wall either. So, Kharto, how do you fit into Erimem's world? What purpose do you serve in it, I wonder?
