DOCTOR: Really? And just who were they, these great founders? What are their names? When did their colony ships arrive? Where are they from?
KHARTO: They were... I don't know. What's wrong with me, Doctor? Why can't I remember anything?
DOCTOR: It's a little complicated to explain. Right now though I think we should concentrate on getting this door open.
KHARTO: Dream on, my friend. You'll never open that door.
DOCTOR: Dream on. Of course. If this is a dreamscape, I can manipulate it. If I can just concentrate.
KHARTO: How did you do that?
DOCTOR: Mind over matter. Come on.
KYLE: (coughs) Dad?
PERI: Kyle? You're awake. I'll fetch the nurse.
KYLE: Wait. Where's Dad?
PERI: He's on his way, honey.
KYLE: I'm half dead and he's... on his way?
PERI: I promise you. He'll be here very soon.
KYLE: I felt so bad, and you just told me to take some pills.
PERI: I made a mistake. I'm... I'm sorry, Kyle. Kyle? Okay, honey. You can hear my apologies later. For now, sleep well and sweet dreams.
ERIMEM: Malarou? Come in please, Malarou, this is Erimem calling. Oh, where has he got to?
ERIMEM: Who's there? Malarou, is that you?
DOCTOR: No, Erimem, it's me. The Doctor.
ERIMEM: Doctor? But you... This can't be happening. This is some kind of trick. You changed, you... you left me.
DOCTOR: Erimem, please, you have to listen to me. This colony, this world, none of it's real. It's an illusion. A dream.
ERIMEM: Are you mad? Why would I dream about rebels, and food tasters dying and servants betraying me?
DOCTOR: Your dream is being directed, controlled by parasitic plants we encountered on an alien world.
ERIMEM: Stop it, Doctor, you're frightening me.
KHARTO: Doctor, someone's coming up the passageway. Guards, I think. I'll hold them off as long as I can.
DOCTOR: Thank you, Kharto. We won't be long.
ERIMEM: Kharto? But he was locked up. What's going on, Doctor?
DOCTOR: This world, it doesn't make sense. It's a mishmash of your old home on Earth and the kinds of frontier worlds you visited with me in the Tardis.
ERIMEM: Oh, this is the Terran colony New Cairo on the planet Kandoor, part of the Hyran System.
DOCTOR: There is no such colony, never was, never will be. This is all an illusion and you have to reject it.
KHARTO: [OC]: Keep back, both of you.
DOCTOR: Think about it, Erimem. Where did Kharto get that gun from? He wasn't carrying it when he came in just now. Why is it always the same two guards who appear? Where is everyone else in this great colony?
ERIMEM: I... I need to speak to Malarou. He'll know the truth.
DOCTOR: Malarou doesn't exist. You have to wake up, Erimem. You have to remember. We landed on a jungle planet - you, me and Peri - and we all fell victim to these parasitical telepathic plants.
ERIMEM: But Peri left us, ages ago.
KHARTO: [OC]: Doctor, I can't hold them off. They... argh!
DOCTOR: Where? Tell me where and how Peri left.
ERIMEM: I... I can't remember.
DOCTOR: Because it never happened. It's a detail your subconscious never bothered to establish, like the
DOCTOR: details about how this colony works or how it was founded.
ERIMEM: Oh, this is all madness.
MALAROU: And the madness stops now.
DOCTOR: First Minister Malarou.
MALAROU: Your Highness, this alien is dangerous. He's playing with your mind, but you must be strong. Reject him, ignore his lies. You must accept this reality.
ERIMEM: Must accept this reality? What you know of different realities, Malarou?
MALAROU: Queen Erimem, I merely wish to protect you from this warlock. He has cast a spell on you.
ERIMEM: Have you cast a spell on me, Doctor? How else can you be in my dream but by magic?
DOCTOR: Magic? Nonsense. I'm using some advanced alien technology.
ERIMEM: That sounds like the Doctor I remember.
DOCTOR: I am the Doctor you remember. Now Erimem, close your eyes and listen to me. You are not in this room. This room does not exist. You are in a medical bed in a lab.
MALAROU: No, my Queen. Don't listen to him. The rebellion is crushed. New Cairo is
DOCTOR: There is an air purifier operating in the room. Can you hear it? Feel the air as it passes over your sleeping body.
MALAROU: (fading) Stay with us. Help us build a new world.
DOCTOR: You're asleep, that's all. Now it's time to wake up.
DOCTOR: Erimem?
UKARME: She seems to be coming out of it now, Doctor. Welcome back, by the way. And well done.
DOCTOR: Thank you, Ukarme. Where's Hayton?
UKARME: The Professor had to leave. He went to the med lab.
ERIMEM: Doctor?
DOCTOR: I'm here, Erimem. How are you feeling?
ERIMEM: Like I've been asleep for ages. I had the strangest dream. It was so vivid. Aman called Malarou was there, and so were you. Where are we?
DOCTOR: In a laboratory on the jungle planet YT45.
ERIMEM: And where is Peri?
UKARME: I can answer that one. I found her, Doctor. She's alive. That's why the Professor dashed off. He has her in the med lab now.
DOCTOR: Excellent. Good work, Ukarme. Can you keep an eye on Erimem for me?
UKARME: Of course.
DOCTOR: Then I'll go and see Hayton. He's got some explaining to do.
TANNOY: Consultant to Paediatrics, please. Consultant to Paediatrics.
PERI: Come on, Ally. What's the point of having a best friend if they don't pick up the damn phone? Oh, great. First my boyfriend, now my best friend. Who's going to be next to ignore my call, my mother? Well, when the going gets tough, the tough get going. Home time.
HAYTON: Look at her. Can you see? Incredible, isn't it?
TAKOL: [OC]: If you like that sort of thing.
HAYTON: My theory is correct. The process of absorption leads to a mutation in the DNA structure. Changes are happening at a chemical level in the victim's brain.
TAKOL: [OC]: Giving us a means to unlock telepathic ability in humans.
HAYTON: It certainly looks that way.
TAKOL: [OC]: I need to report this to High Command. Good work, Hayton.
HAYTON: My pleasure. Right then, my dear, let's open you up and see exactly what's going on, shall we?
DOCTOR: Professor. Would you mind putting that laser cutter down and moving away from your patient?
HAYTON: Doctor. It worked, then. Is Erimem awake?
DOCTOR: Never mind Erimem, it's Peri I'm concerned with at the moment.
HAYTON: Peri? Oh, you mean the hybrid here. I'm sorry. I know she was your friend, but there's nothing that can be done for her now.
DOCTOR: How can you be so sure?
HAYTON: Because she's already well into stage three. She won't die in vain, though. She can still be useful to us, as a Subject.
DOCTOR: Leave her alone, Hayton. I'm warning you.
HAYTON: I'm sorry, Doctor. I cannot allow you to stand in the way of scientific advancement because of some trivial emotional attachment you may harbour.
UKARME: Here. Have some water.
ERIMEM: Thank you. Ukarme, is it?
UKARME: Yes. I was the one who found you out in the jungle, and brought you back here.
ERIMEM: Then I am indebted to you.
UKARME: Oh, I'm just glad to see you up and about. How are you feeling?
ERIMEM: Very strange. I'm not entirely convinced that this is not a dream too.
UKARME: What was it like, when you were in the dream place?
ERIMEM: It felt... (sighs)... real.
UKARME: You had no idea that you were dreaming?
ERIMEM: Not really. Everything seemed to make sense at the time. I was the ruler of a space colony.
UKARME: (laughs) Really? You must have a very well-developed ego.
ERIMEM: (laughs) You should have seen me back home.
UKARME: Little Miss Absolute Ruler.
ERIMEM: (laughs) You have no idea.
PERI: Mike? I'm home, honey. Where have you been? I was beginning to panic until I saw your car out front. Mike? Mike? Is that you?
PERI: Mike? Ally?
ALLY: Oh my God. Peri.
MIKE: I... I can explain.
PERI: What's to explain? I've just found my boyfriend in my bedroom with my best friend. Doesn't get much clearer than that.
MIKE: No, wait, please, just hear me out.
PERI: I don't want to. Just leave me alone!
MIKE: Peri? Peri?
ERIMEM: It was so real, you could taste it. More vivid than anything I've ever dreamt before.
UKARME: And how do you feel now? Does your dream seem less real?
ERIMEM: Not at the moment. Maybe it will in time. Why are you so interested? I thought you were a soldier, not a scientist.
UKARME: Maybe there is more to me than just this uniform.
ERIMEM: I'm sorry, Ukarme, that was rude of me. I don't know you at all. I'd no right to make assumptions.
UKARME: It is I who should apologise to you. I haven't been entirely honest with you.
ERIMEM: Oh, I should have known. You were too polite for a soldier. Well, are you going to kill me or make me your prisoner?
DOCTOR: Is that what this is all about? Scientific advancement?
HAYTON: Why else would I be risking my life in this hell-hole? It's hardly a top vacation spot.
DOCTOR: So that's why you had samples of the plant extract ready to hand. You're planning to sell it on the open market.
HAYTON: The mind controlling properties alone make it commercially viable, but thanks to your friend here, I may also be able to isolate the chemical that stimulates telepathic ability. Think of the possible markets for a drug like that.
DOCTOR: I cannot allow it.
HAYTON: And who are you to stop me?
DOCTOR: I'm the Doctor.
HAYTON: Ah, of course! You're FDA, aren't you?
DOCTOR: FDA?
HAYTON: Don't play dumb. The Federation Drugs Administration. I knew you pen-pushing bureaucrats would eventually catch up with me. Well, you can tell your bosses they can forget it. I'll bypass their ridiculously long and expensive drugs trials and make a fortune before they can do a thing about it.
DOCTOR: And what about the military who funded this mission? How are they going to feel about you taking this for your own?
HAYTON: Takol's a fool, and so are High Command.
MIKE: Peri, come back! It's not how it looks!
PERI: Leave me alone. How could you do that to me? To your son!
MIKE: Peri, look out!

elements.text: [Part Three]
Is this... death? Is this what it feels like to die? (rapid beeping) Somehow I thought it'd be... quieter.
What is it, Hayton? What's wrong?
The girl's vital signs are flat-lining. Something must have happened in her dream, some trauma or shock.
Then we have to do something.
Stop that, Doctor. You could do more damage than good.
I can't just stand here and do nothing.
That's exactly what you have to do. I'm not interested in keeping this specimen alive. I need to see what happens when brain death occurs, how the plant reacts.
You're inhuman.
Look who's talking. Now step away or regrettably I'll be forced to shoot you.
What?
Keep your hands where I can see them.
I thought you were a man of science.
I thought you were too.
Laser shot. Hayton cries out, thud.
Pick the gun up, Doctor. I only set mine to stun, so he could come to at any moment.
What are you doing here, Major?
The idiot left the vid-link active, I heard every treacherous word that escaped his boastful lips.
Well, they say pride comes before a fall. Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to help Peri. What have we here? Ah, adrenalin. Forty ccs should do it.
Hiss of injector.
Will that help?
We'll have to wait and see. What will you do with the Professor now?
He'll be relieved of duty and confined to quarters. He can be put on the brig when we get to the mothership.
You're leaving?
Got to get off this rock before nightfall.
Peri. Can you hear me, Peri?
How is she?
Stabilising. Her vital signs are recovering, but I need to get into her dream.
Let's get the Professor here safely locked away, then we can see what can be done to help your friend.
Where am I?
Outside the house, honey. You were lucky. The car only glanced you.
What? It hit me full-on. I... I felt it. I was as good as dead.
Looking good for a corpse, kiddo.
Where is Ally?
Calling for an ambulance to take you to the hospital. Don't worry. Everything's going to be okay.
Where are you taking me?
There's something I want to show you. Here.
A door? Believe me, I've seen one before.
You won't have seen what's inside before.
Door opens.
The sign says Keep Out - Quarantine Area.
Don't worry, it's safe. Come on.
This is ridiculous. You can't lock me up like this.
Watch me.
I'm well-connected. You're making a big mistake.
No, Professor, it is you who have made a mistake. I am in command of this mission and I will not tolerate any insubordination. Goodbye.
Door closes.
[OC]: Takol!
I've taken Peri to the lab. Will Hayton be secure in there?
As long as we're not here after nightfall.
What happens after dark?
The monsters come out.
I take it that's not a metaphorical statement?
This planet has a diurnal cycle that lasts about a hundred and fourteen hours. During the day it's a
lovely place if you can stomach the heat, the mud slides and the murderous plants, but at night, it's something else.
How long have we got before sunset?
The shuttle's due to land in half an hour. We evacuate fifteen minutes later.
Then we don't have much time. I have to get Peri out of that dream state.
This is the remains of the original expedition to this horrible planet.
What happened here? It's like a disaster zone.
The base was overrun by those Jekyll things that live in the jungle.
Like that creature in the laboratory? It didn't seem hostile.
Not everything is what it seems, Erimem.
Who are you, Ukarme? What's really going on here?
Right, I'll make the connections, but I'll need you to inject me with the plant extract.
I think I can manage that.
It's vitally important that no attempt is made to wake either of us during this procedure. It could be very dangerous.
Understood.
And will you check on Erimem for me? I'm not sure where she's got to.
Don't worry, Doctor. Ukarme's probably showing her the base, but I'll make sure she's safe.
Thank you. Now, let's get on with this. The sooner I can start interfacing with Peri, the sooner I can help her.
Roll up your sleeve, then.
[TV]: Previously on Love MD.
[TV]: Clamp. Clamp! What's wrong with you? Do you want this kid to bleed to death? Guido?
The doctor says you were really lucky. Hardly a mark on you. You can leave here tonight.
And Kyle?
He's here. Don't worry. I had you moved in with him. Got to keep all my eggs in one basket. (laughs) It's all right. He's doing fine. But we're not out of the woods yet.
I didn't take it seriously. I thought he just had a headache.
You weren't to know.
I make a rotten stepmother.
I'd have done the same as you. Look, about what happened with Ally. I can explain.
What's to explain?
It wasn't what it looked like. I love you, Peri, and only you.
Oh, right. You love me, but you were with her. How does that work, then?
Nothing was going on, I promise.
I see. I find Ally in her underwear with you, and Im meant to believe that nothing is going on?
It was meant to be a surprise for you.
Well, that bit worked.
She was trying on a dress. Adress I'd bought for you.
Oh, come on. You've never bought me a dress before.
True, but then I've never had to plan a surprise wedding before either.
What?

Ally's been helping me. She's the same build as you, so she was trying on the dress to see if it would fit you. I was going to surprise you with the whole thing. The last-minute holiday to the Caribbean, the spontaneous proposal, a wedding dress waiting in the cabin. I'd been planning it for months.
But, I...
Oh well, this isn't the way I wanted to do it, but what the heck. Perpugilliam Brown, will you marry me?
I'm an undercover agent of the FDA. That's the Federation Drugs Administration.
You're some kind of policeman?
Six months ago, a routine survey mission visited this place and stumbled upon the unique properties of the indigenous plant life, the kyropites.
The plants that make you dream?
Exactly.
But why come undercover?

Well, we couldn't be certain what happened here. Parts of the survey report were missing, the data was corrupted, and there was the suggestion of a cover-up, but not enough real evidence for us to act.
Couldn't you simply talk to the people who came here?
None of them survived.
I'm sorry.
So am I. Four people died here. Listen to this. It's the last message that was received from the survey crew.

[OC]: This is Captain Aranda issuing a warning to all spacefarers. You must keep away from this planet. It's hostile, repeat, hostile and dangerous. If this recording reaches the outside world, please tell my family I love them. We thought this planet was a paradise, but we were wrong. It's deadly. The plants, the wildlife. All...(glass breaks, screams and growls.)
Captain Aranda was my sister.
In the background was that a... a Jekyll?
Yes. The Jekylls killed the survey crew, and then shared their kill with the plants.
If the creatures attack that crew, might they not do the same to this one?

We expect them to, as soon as night falls. Which is why the shuttle is due to land any moment. But I have enough evidence now to make my report on what Hayton's been doing here. I just need to make sure it reaches my bosses back home.
Why not just report him to the Major?
Takol? That wouldn't be a very good idea. She's Hayton's partner in this.
Pouring liquid, clink of glasses.
Cheers.
Takol laughs.
Was this charade really necessary, Takol? Tasering me then locking me up in my cabin?
Don't be petulant. I needed the time to think. If the Doctor is FDA, we need to play this carefully.
I think killing him would have solved all our problems here.
It's far better he dies in an accident while investigating your procedures.
Whatever. As long as he doesn't jeopardise the operation.
Look, Peri, I can see this has come as a bit of a shock.
You can say that again.
Why don't I try and rustle us up a couple of coffees? Give you some time alone to think about it.
Yeah, sure.
Keep an eye on Kyle now. Make sure he doesn't go running off.
I will. Er, thanks, Mike.
Two coffees coming right up.
Oh. Would you know if I'd find Miss Brown in there?
Sorry, who are you?
I'm the Doctor.
Are you the consultant that's looking after our son?
No. No, not exactly. I've, er... Your son? I wasn't aware that Peri had a...
Oh right, yeah, my son. But Peri is his stepmother. Or will be when we get married. I've just proposed, actually.
Then I suppose congratulations are in order. Look, would you mind if I went in there for a few moments? The consultant asked me to, er, provide a second opinion.
About Kyle? Surely it's either meningitis or it's not?
Well, I think it's best I take a look just in case. Belt and braces, eh?
Okay, then. You'd better go in.
No one about. Good. Well, there they are.
Door closes.
Peri! What's happened to her?
The plant is beginning to bond with her DNA. The Doctor is attempting to get through to her telepathically.
Like he did with me?
Exactly, but Peri is in a much later stage of this thing. It's not going to be easy for him.
[OC]: Ukarme, where are you?
Er, checking the harvesters, sir.
[OC]: Get back inside this base immediately.
Will do, sir. How are the Doctor and his companions?

[OC]: There have been developments since you left the base. It transpires that the Doctor and his friends are hostile alien spies. The Doctor managed to stun the Professor and make his getaway, and we haven't seen his accomplice for some time. Be on your guard, Ukarme. They are to be shot on sight, understand?
Yes, sir.
[OC]: Takol out.
Sounds like the Major's decided to show her true colours.
Well, we can't move the Doctor and Peri, so we'll just have to make sure Takol and co can't get to
us. Here, help me with this table.
Will this hold them?
Not on its own, no. If I can just reprogramme this default, I can override the door controls and lock us in. There. That'll stop 'em for a while.
Rumble.
What was that?
The shuttle's coming in. We're running out of time. Whatever the Doctor is doing, he'd better do it
quickly.
Ah, doctor. Come to see how he is, then?
I see things have progressed further than I'd hoped.
But Kyle is going to be okay, isn't he?
I wasn't talking about the boy, I'm talking about you. You don't recognise me, do you?
I'm sorry. Did we meet before?
Peri, I know this will sound strange, but you have to believe me. You are dreaming. This whole thing, the hospital, your boyfriend, your son, none of it is real.
What kind of a doctor are you?
I'm not a doctor, I'm the Doctor. Now, Peri, please, concentrate. Look at me. What do you see?
A chubby man with glasses and a nasty case of acne.
Really? Look again. What am I wearing?
A white coat, of course, and a stethoscope round your neck.
And in my lapel?
Your lapel? It's a... a stick of celery. Doctor?
Be careful with them. Those plant samples are priceless.
Affirmative, Professor Hayton.
Calm yourself, Hayton. I programmed the drones myself. They'll be more than capable of conveying the samples on board safely.
I didn't realise we'd be in such a hurry. How long have we got?
About ten minutes until nightfall. As soon as we're loaded I'm taking off.
I'll get Ukarme and the girl. We need her. She's a perfect specimen of the advanced stage.
Be quick. I won't wait.
You're all heart, Major.
But that's not possible, Doctor. I left you years ago.
Peri? Mum?
Kyle! Oh, you called me mum.
Dad told me I had to start getting used to the idea.
Mike! Kyle's awake.
Peri, please, you have to listen to me.

I'm sorry, Doctor, but my son has just had a brush with death, and... and I've been hit by a car and then proposed to. My life is complicated enough right now without you trying to tell me it's not real.
Door opens.
Mike! He's back with us.
That's fantastic news.
Peri, this isn't real. It's like some bad soap opera concocted by your imagination.
Go away, Doctor. Mummy doesn't need you.
Yes, Doctor. Get out and leave us alone.
I think you should go now, Doctor.
Growling nearby.
[OC]: Ukarme. What's going on? Open these doors immediately. I need to check on the Doctor and the girl.
I'm sorry, Professor, that isn't possible.
[OC]: That is an order, soldier.
I'm sorry, Professor, but I take my orders from the FDA.
[OC]: So you're the FDA spy. I knew the Doctor was too stupid to be one of their operatives.
If I were you, Professor, I'd find a place of safety. It sounds like the Jekylls may have got your scent.
[OC]: The Jekylls? So soon?
It's nightfall out in the jungle. Time for the hunt.
[OC]: You'll pay for this, Ukarme. Once we're in space I'll get the Major to destroy this laboratory.
I'd hurry if I were you.
Shouldn't we let it out? The Jekyll?
Are you kidding? It'd rip us to shreds in a second.
Rumbling.
The shuttle?
Taking off with a cargo full of plants, I'll bet.
But if those things get off this planet, they'll spread like some kind of plague.
Not if I can help it.
Major Takol to mothership. Come in, Lieutenant Anders.
ANDERS [OC]: (a woman) Anders here, sir.
Shuttle is leaving the planet's troposphere. Estimated docking time - thirty minutes.
ANDERS [OC]: Sir, we're picking up an odd reading here. Scans are showing some fluctuation in your engine performance.
No sign of anything here.
ANDERS [OC]: Sir, I suggest you get to a life pod immediately.
Don't over-react, Anders, it's probably just a fault...
KaBOOM!
Jekylls roar. Shots fired. Banging on door.
Please, Ukarme. You've got to let me in, in the name of humanity. They're ripping the base to shreds.
[OC]: Humanity? It's a bit late for that now, isn't it?
I went to the shuttle, but Takol had already taken off. She abandoned me.
Jekylls roaring. Shots fired.
Please! They're breaking in everywhere. I can help you. I can help the Doctor and Peri. Please!
Look, either you leave of your own accord, or I make you leave.
Peri, concentrate. This isn't real, any of it. You're on an alien planet with me and Erimem.
Erimem? But she was killed by crocodile-things.
The Krillian Horde? No, we escaped from them.
I'm going to fetch an orderly.
There aren't any orderlies, they don't exist. This hospital doesn't exist.
Don't listen to him, Mum.
Think, Peri. If you remember Erimem leaving, you must remember your own departure.
Of course.
Tell me about it.
Well, I... I, I can't remember.
Something as important as that? Giving up the opportunity to travel in Time and Space? You can't remember?
It must have been the accident. I was stuck by a... by...
Distant explosion and screams.
Oh my God! A petrol tanker's crashed into A & E! Quick, we have to get out!
Mum, please, help me.
Peri, your subconscious is doing everything it can to keep you here, but you have to give this life up. It's not your life, not yet.
But... my family.
We have to go. The building is gonna collapse.
Mum, please. I need your help. I can't make it without you.
It's a trap, Peri.
Glass breaks.
Peri! My leg! Please, help me!
Mum, I can't move. Help.
Mike! Kyle!
Choose a reality, Peri. This madness or life in the Tardis. Choose!
An ambulance siren adds to the commotion.
Choose! (echoes.)
Let him in, Ukarme, we need him.
He's a murderer. He wanted Peri to die.
And what are you? There were people on that shuttle. Did you think about them?
The shuttle has an Al pilot system. The only passenger was Major Takol. And after what she did
here, I won't be shedding any tears for her. But I'll let him in if that's what you want.
Door opens.
Thank you, Ukarme. They were going to... He's escaping from his cage!
Erimem, look out! Give me that gun.
Two shots fired, Jekyll cries out, thud.
You didn't have to kill it.
Ten more seconds and he'd have been free to kill us all. Just like his compatriots out there, this is the jungle. It's kill or be killed.
Choose.
Doctor?
Hayton, can you revive him?
I can try and force him to wake, but it's very dangerous.
Judging by the readouts on these screens, he's dying anyway.
I'll try a neural stimulant.
Get a move on. Those doors won't hold forever.
Is it working?
No. He's gone into cardiac arrest. Stand back. We're losing him.
If he dies, I'm sending you back outside.
Well?
I don't know.
Did you do both hearts?
Doctor!
Erimem. How nice to see you again. How's Peri?
Mike. Kyle.
Peri, it's me, Erimem.
Erimem? I thought you were dead.
Remarkable. The plant tissue is simply falling away.
Make your observations later, Professor. We need to get out of here.
I agree. Whatever's behind those doors, it doesn't sound very happy. Is there another way out?
These units are plastic. We should be able to cut our way directly through to the jungle.
Excellent. Let's get on with it.
It's clear. No beasts around at the moment.
Right then. We need to get to the Tardis.
The what?
Our ship. It's a big blue box.
Where is it?
I don't know. Where did you first find me?
Sector four north, by some caves.
Excellent. Take us there. Come on, Hayton.
But what about the Jekylls?
If we're quick we shouldn't have a problem. They're too busy ripping the base apart to bother with us.
Can I at least have my weapon back?
I don't think so. You take it, Doctor.
Ah, no. No, thank you. I've never liked the things. Give it to Erimem. Besides, I'll have my hands full carrying Peri.
This way.
Doctor, that vine. Get down!
Thank you.
Here comes some more!
It's the plants. They're not going to let us go without a fight.
Help me.
They've got the Professor!
I'll go back for him. You go on.
Don't be stupid, man. The vines are thicker back there than anywhere.
(distant) No! Please!
Just take this. My report.
(distant) No! Argh!
Make sure it reaches the FDA.
I promise.
Go! The caves are just through those trees. Your blue box must be there somewhere. Argh!
Ukarme!
Doctor, we have to get Peri back to the Tardis.
No. You go. Help her. I must try and save Ukarme and Hayton.
But it's too late, Doctor!
I have to try, Erimem. Now, hurry!
Doctor, wait!
Just get back to the Tardis!
Doctor!
Ow, my leg.
Don't move. It's a sprain, that's all. You fell, little brother.
Aranda?
The grass has cushioned your fall.
But.. but you... you died.
No, I found a way to survive. Down here there's a hollow, away from where those plants grow. I've been here all this time. I survived, Ukarme, and so can you.
We don't have to hide any more, Aranda. We can leave. We just need to get to the Doctor's blue box.
His Tardis?
Yes. It's not far. Help me.
Banging on door, Tardis door opens.
Ukarme. Are we glad to see you. We thought it was those horrible Jekylls. Come into the Tardis, quickly.
We managed to give them the slip. Erimem, this is my sister Aranda.
Pleased to meet you.
Likewise.
And this is the Doctor.
Aranda, I've heard so much about you. It's a pleasure to finally meet you face-to-face.
This is a very impressive spacecraft, Doctor.
One does one's best. I'm sure Peri would like to say hello. Erimem, would you take Aranda down to the lower decks? Thanks.
Certainly. This way.
Walking on metal.
This is the nose cone, I take it?
Yes. The rest of the ship buries itself on landing, leaving only the blue cone visible.
Ingenious.
Useful. Listen, Ukarme, would you and your sister like to stay with us? Travel the galaxy? We could do with crew members of your calibre.
Doctor, I'd... well... I'd love to.
Excellent. Well, your first duty is to press the launch controls and start the countdown.
My pleasure.
Rumbling.
Ten, nine, eight, seven...
Six, five, four...
No. Ukarme...
Three.
Fight against it, man.
Two.
Don't let the plants...
One.
Take over your mind.
Lift off.
Ukarme.
How are you feeling?
(drinks) Groggy. I feel like I've swallowed a ton of earth. Where's the Doctor?
He, er... he went to rescue Hayton and Ukarme, and...
And what?
And he's not back yet. It's been an hour.
Then we need to go look for him.
You're in no fit state to go out there.
Oh, we're not just leaving him there. He may need our help. He may need...
Tardis doors open.
Oh, Doctor! Are we pleased to see you. Boy, you look pretty beaten up. Are you okay?
Where's Ukarme? And Hayton? Doctor?
Shut the doors, Erimem.
Tardis doors close.
Well, Doctor?
What are you doing?
Transmitting Ukarme's report to his bosses.
Doctor, where is Ukarme?
Dead.
Dead?
I couldn't save him. He was too far gone when I found them. Hayton and Ukarme side by side, covered in tendrils.
Surely we can do something?
Peri, don't you think I tried?
Hayton wanted to experiment on you, Peri. And Ukarme? well, he had excellent motives, but - his methods were without honour. Peri?
I'll be in my room if you want me. Too many people have died today. Too many. (internal door opens) My son among them.
Door closes.
Doctor, Peri dreamt of having a family and settling down. Is that because she lost her own family so young?
Perhaps.
And me, I dreamt of... leaving you. What does that say about me? That I want to go home?
I honestly don't know. Do you want to stop travelling with us?
Perhaps.
Maybe our next destination will help you make up your mind.
And where will that be?
Who knows? The universe is ours to explore, Erimem. Your destiny can wait.
Mission of the Viyrans, by Colin Brake A Big Finish Productions Dr Who Audio Drama, released Nov 2007
(a machine voice) Memory zero. Negative. Reset.
Beep!
(gasps) Hello? Anybody there?
Walking on wood. Water flowing. Distant music from a party.
Nice night. Party too much for you? Contemplating jumping in? Hey!
Oh! Sorry, I didn't hear you. Er, well, yes. I thought it best to leave you having a good time.
You were miles away there. What were you thinking about?
Thinking about? Er... That's odd, actually. I don't seem to remember.
Ha! That's old age for you.
Old age. That's old age for you.
Er, that's what I just said, Doctor. You sure you're okay?
Okay. Peri.
That's me.
Peri, something's wrong. I feel...
Whoa! Hey! It's all right. You were the one who warned me about the Grallistan punch.
Grallistan punch.
Punch, yeah. Whoa, you really are the worse for wear.
Old age. Party too much. Miles away.
Let me remind you, it was your idea to come here. You said I needed to relax and enjoy myself, after...
Miles... away!
Cracking noises.
What the hell's happening? Doctor! Somebody help me! Hey! Oh, I don't believe it.
Don't...
2: ... Believe it.
What? No, this can't be happening.
2: Miles away.
No ... Doctor!
2: Miles away.
Doctor, where are you? What the hell is going on? (echoes)

Recall and delete. It was night. The Doctor was standing on a small wooden bridge looking into a stream. At first he did not notice when you spoke to him. When he did, he seemed distracted, confused. You thought he was intoxicated. Then he began to collapse and repeat the words you had spoken to him. Before your eyes his face changed into an exact replica of your face.
(gasps) Hello? Anyone there? Anyone feel like maybe turning a light on?
There is no light.
Right. Okay. I kinda gathered that.
There is no light that you can see.
Okay. Got that. Thanks.
There is light that you cannot see, beyond your visual spectrum.
Well, thanks for pointing that out. Er...
What do you remember?
Im not sure what you mean.
What were you just remembering?
Well, I was... I was asleep, wasn't I?
No.
But I must have been.
Why do you say that?
Because I think I was dreaming that... Actually, that's none of your business. Dreams are private, and - and who are you, anyway?
Don't you remember?
Am I supposed to?
2: Don't you remember?
But... where am I?
2: Don't you remember?
Who are you?
2: I need you to answer the question.
You sound like me. Is it a trick? What's going on?
Is it a trick?
2: Is it a trick?
A trick?
2: A trick? A trick?
Stop it! Why are you playing a trick on me?
2: I want to know what you remember.
Are you just trying to freak me out or something?
Is that better? Are you less freaked out now?
Yes, I guess.
Do you remember this happening before?
Why? Has it happened before?
Tell us what you were remembering before you said...
[recording]: Hello? Anyone there?
Don't do that.
Please be honest. It is the only way for us to be sure.
Us? Who are you? And why do you keep pretending to be me?
We are not pretending to be you. We are the Viyrans.
Viyrans?
And there is a matter of urgency. Did you remember the Doctor?
The Doctor? What do you know about the Doctor?
Please answer the question.
What if I don't?
Please answer the question. Very well. You leave us no choice.
What do you mean? Is that a threat? Hello?
A noise gets louder.
What's that? Is that you? What are you doing? Will you give me some answers, for...
Disco music playing.
Hey. Hey! I need some help out here. l...
Music stops.
What happened here? Anybody awake? What's the matter? You can't all just have... Chris. Chris, wake up!
Slapping face.
What's the ... what's the matter?
Oh, thank God. I don't know, Chris. Something really weird just happened out there with the Doctor. You remember the Doctor, right?
What happened here?
I don't know. How come everyone just... well, flaked out? Was it too much punch, or...?
Anybody awake?
No, not as far as I can tell, apart from you. Anyway, you've gotta come with me. I don't even know if what I saw was - I don't know - real. Oh, come on, Chris, get up, will you?
Muttering from the others.
Chris?
Chris. Chris, wake up.
What?
Chris. Chris.
Oh no. Oh, no, no, no, no. Please, this cannot be happening.
1: Wake up.
2: Wake up.
No, stop it. Stop it.
Stop it.
No. Stop it. (repeating)
No! No!
(gasps) What's going on? Tell me, whoever you are. You know something. Stop playing games and just...
You were remembering something.
Was I?
Your brain activity indicated you were remembering something. We must know what you were remembering.
If you're monitoring my brain somehow, can't you tell me? Or aren't you that smart?
We are not that smart. We cannot read minds. That is not our purpose.
Then what is your purpose? I have a right to know.
We are not concerned with your rights. There is a matter of urgency. You are remembering incidents and we need to know what they are.
Why?
It is better if you do not know.
Oh, really? Why?
It would be simpler if you trusted us.
Simpler for you, you mean.
Simpler and better for many.
Many? Like who?
We will not answer such questions.
Why not? Okay, I admit it. I remembered something.
Yes. We know that. But we must know what it was.
And if I don't tell you you'll hurt me again, right? Can't you see that there's no way I'm going to trust you if you threaten me. You have to earn my trust.
Tell us the first thing you remembered before you said...
[recording]: Hello? Anybody there?
All right. Well, I was at a party on Grallista Social. I noticed the Doctor had left the party and...

(speeded up) Recall and delete. It was night. The Doctor was standing on a small wooden bridge looking into a stream. At first he did not notice when you spoke to him. When he did, he seemed distracted, confused. You thought he was intoxicated. Then he began to collapse and repeat the words you had spoken to him. Before your eyes his face changed into an exact replica of your face.
(distant, echoes) No, Doctor!
Who are you people?
We told you. We are the Viyrans. There is a matter of urgency. To tell you more would be to build significant new memories. We must not do that.
Significant? Will you tell me how you knew what I remembered?
Very well. This will be our one concession to engender your trust. We knew of your memory because you have told us of it before.
When?
Precisely three hundred and thirty seven times previous to this treatment period.
Three hundred and...?
Will you trust us now, Peri?
It's a treatment?
What is the next thing you remember, Peri? Memory is not always chronological.
I remember... Erimem. I remember her.
That memory is permitted.
Permitted?
What is the next thing you remember relating to the planet Grallista Social?
Okay. I... I went back into the party hut to get help, and when I got there everyone was ... I don't know, lying down - unconscious, I guess. I woke Chris up. He spoke, but then...
Please continue, Peri.
I'm not sure I can remember what happened next. It was weird. I mean, I remember remembering it, if you see what I mean, like a dream you remember having, but you can't quite...
And the next thing you remember?
Something... something about having a son. Kyle? No, but that's not true. Is it?
We don't know. That is for you to decide.

So... maybe this stuff about Grallista Social and the Doctor changing, changing into me - I mean, it's just crazy. Maybe that's not true either. Dracula! I remember Dracula, we lost the Tardis, and - and...
Concentrate on Grallista Social. What happened when you first arrived on Grallista Social?
The Tardis materialises.
1: Did you go to the last one?
2: Yeah, it was fantastic.
Tardis door opens.
Grallista Social? (laughs) They actually called this planet Social?
Tardis door closes.
Well, that way everyone knows what to expect when they come here.
Socialising. Hmm. I'm not sure if I'm in the mood for socialising.
I know. Which is precisely why we should come here and socialise. We've had enough heartache lately. Time to unwind.
Nobody here seems particularly fazed by a blue box appearing out of nowhere, do they?
Nothing seems to faze anyone on Grallista Social. Take a leaf out of their book, Peri. Relax, have a nice time, meet new people. And just wait till you've tasted the infamous Grallistan punch.
Buzz, Peri coughs.
You haven't tasted it yet.
No, it's not... (coughs) that. Ugh. I think I've just swallowed a fly or something.
Oh. I don't see any flies.
Mmm, maybe not. It felt like something hit the back of my throat, like it shot in there really fast. It feels numb. The sensation's kind of fading now. (muffled) Yeah. Think it's okay. Weird.
I remember the bright light.
Whining.
Ah! No. It hurts.
Try to forget the light.

Chris's face. Everyone's face. The Doctor, everyone. They all started to look just like me. It was like a nightmare. I wanted to wake up, get away. I ran out of the hut, there... there was this, this car thing, I got in it, I pushed every button, and it started to move. I found the accelerator, I drove as fast as I could. I thought I was going mad. The lights of the party were a long way behind me. I didn't know where I was going, what I was trying to get away from. I was just terrified. Then suddenly my headlights caught somebody.
Hey!
Screech of brakes, thud. Car stops.
I'm sorry. Sorry. Are you okay?
I, yeah. No bones broken, I think.
I'm sorry.
You said. Where have you come from?
Er, where? Er, well, one of the party huts.
Out west?
I think so. I'm not sure.
Then it's happened there too.
What? What's happened?
Well, I assumed you were trying to get away, the speed you were driving.
I was, but how did you...? Were you trying to get away too?
From the space pad, yeah. What are you looking at?
Er, nothing. It's just good to see a friendly face, that's all. A different face.
Do you know who they were? Hey, wait a minute. Listen.
It's coming from that direction, from the party huts where I came from.
A sudden whoosh.
Whoa!
What was that?
I don't know. It was moving too fast. Fast, and, I don't know, shiny. Something fast and shiny, glowing.
And flying. Look out!
Ah! They're heading in the direction you were coming from.
They must be connected to those creatures in some way.
Creatures? What... what creatures?
At the space pad. I thought that's who you were trying to get away from.
Creatures? No. Well, I, I don't know if you'd call them that exactly.
What would you call them, then? Look out!
Wait a minute. Look. They look like... like there are people inside whatever they are.
Like coffins.
Coffins?
Flying glass coffins.
What's your name?
Lawrence, actually. Pleased to meet you.
Peri.
Peri. Hi. Sorry, should have done that earlier, I suppose.
They laugh.

Lawrence, something seriously weird is going on here. And... well, to tell you the truth, I feel kind of like I'm going insane. So will you do me a real favour, Lawrence, and tell me what you saw at the space pad. Lawrence?
That.
What?
Behind you. That's what I saw.
And these are the creatures you were talking about?
These are the creatures.
Do you know who they are?
Are the creatures.
I know, but do you know who...?
Cracking sounds.
Please, no. (cries) Get away from me. Keep away!
2: These are the creatures.
No!
Banging.
Let me out of this thing. Who are you?
A speeded-up jumble of Peri's words, then a whirring.
Stop making that noise.
2: Language assimilated.
That's my voice.
2: We have been searching for you. You are Patient Zero.
Patient? Stop speaking with my voice.
2: Your language has been assimilated through a recording of your voice. We have never encountered your species before.
Change the voice. It's creepy. Looking at you but hearing me? I... I don't like it.
Is this sufficiently different?
I guess so. Who are you? What are you? Is that a spacesuit? Is there someone inside?
We are the Viyrans. You are Patient Zero.
What do you mean by Patient Zero?
Have we not assimilated your language correctly? Vocalisation is not easy for us. We are achieving it artificially. We have no vocal language.
But Patient Zero? I mean... I understand the term, but - well, it means the first person infected by something.
Then you understand.
Oh, really? That's a bit of a leap.
It is not necessary for you to understand fully. You must be cured, and the memory of this incident expunged.
Cured of what? Oh! No! Oh, turn that light off, it's hurting me! No! Please! No!
Excuse me. Hello. It's Chris, isn't it?
Er, yeah. Oh, you're Peri's friend, aren't you, the Doctor?
Yes, yes, that's right. You've seen her, then?
Well, not since last night. All a bit hectic last night.
Hectic, was it?
Well, I mean, it was a great party, wasn't it? You were there, weren't you? I seem to remember seeing you.
Yes, but I left early. Are you sure it was only last night?
What do you mean? Course it was only last night. Why do you ask?
Er, I don't know. Just seems longer ago.
Oh, that'll be the punch.
Yeah. Oh yes, of course, the punch, yes, hmm.
I should get back to bed if I were you, sleep it off.
I must say, I feel fully rested. It's just that...
Just what?
Have you seen Peri this morning? We'd arranged to meet, and, well, I'm worried about her.
Oh. Well, last thing I remember, shed left the party to see where you'd gone, said she'd drag you back. Didn't see her again.
I see.
Didn't she find you?
Er, I'm afraid I don't know.
Well, she couldn't have done, could she, if you're looking for her?
No, no, I suppose not.
Look, Doctor, there's another party tonight. Mind if I give you some advice?
Not at all, Chris.
I'd give it a miss if I were you. Settle yourself down with a nice cup of chocolate and a boring book.
Memory zero, negative. You have remembered more, again.
Wait a minute. You're trying to make me forget something, right?
The memory must be expunged.
Because you want me to have as little as possible to forget?
It is unfortunate. Two of you must be expunged.
Expunged? You mean you're going to kill me? Stop it, wait!
Do you wish to cooperate with us?
Of course I do, if the alternative is you killing me. And what did you mean, two of us have to be expunged?

The one you call the Doctor. His mind is more complex than yours. There is a point zero zero zero zero one zero memory fragment that is permissible if there is a memory zero patient present, whose lack of memory will prevent memory stimulation. But if you are not present, there is too high a risk of the Doctor rebuilding his memory. He must therefore also be expunged.
The trouble is that I don't even understand what it is I'm supposed not to remember, if you see what I mean.
After neutralisation and inoculation was completed, we attempted three hundred and thirty eight times to achieve memory zero.
Well, hey, why stop now? You've obviously been having such fun.
For the last one hundred and eleven attempts, your memory has rebuilt itself further.
You mean, I end up remembering more than I did when you started.

During the first two hundred and twenty seven attempts, your memory decreased significantly, but since then, it has started to increase. Our time here is limited. Further attempts are clearly pointless and would serve only to provoke total recall.
I see.
Therefore you must be expunged.
Wait. I've got an idea.
There is not much time. The matter is urgent.
Did I ever understand what had happened to me?
No, not fully. The explanations were outside your frame of reference, and we sought to preserve those areas of ignorance.

Well, that's it, then. Because I never understood what had happened in the first place, I was left with too many nagging questions in my mind. Each time you tried to assess how much memory had been removed, I started trying to work out what had happened and what I'd forgotten.
I do not understand the point you are making.
I think I have to want to forget.
Tardis door opens.
Peri. How long have you been here?
Are you okay? You look worried.
What? No, well...
Tardis door closes.
Yes, I am worried. I thought you were... I don't know what I thought. Are you all right?
Course I'm all right. We said we'd meet back here in the Tardis, didn't we?
Did we? Yes, I suppose we did.
Well then, here we are, then. What did you get up to last night?
Last night?
After you left the party.
Are you sure it was last night?
Er, yeah. Doctor, are you sure you didn't have any of that punch?
Peri, what exactly happened the last time you saw me?
Water nearby. Distant music.
Nice night. Party too much for you? Contemplating jumping in? Hey!
Oh! Sorry, I didn't hear you. Er, well, yes. I thought it best to leave you having a good time.
You were miles away there. What were you thinking about?
Thinking about? Er... That's odd, actually. I don't seem to remember.
Ha! That's old age for you.
You know, I think it probably is. I think I might go back to the Tardis, if you don't mind.
I promised Chris I'd drag you back in there.
Er, I think Chris would be happier if he could drag you back in there.
Hmm. Maybe.
See you back at the Tardis tomorrow morning. Have fun.
And that's what happened?
That's what happened.
Are you sure?
Yeah, sure, why?
I don't know. To tell you the truth, I can't even remember why I brought it up. Did you enjoy yourself last night?
I had a great time, really great, but...
But what?
(sighs) I still feel, well, kinda sad.
Ah. You mean Erimem.
Yeah.
Do you honestly think she'd have wanted us to be sad?
No, I guess not.
I'm not suggesting it'll be easy, it never is, but there's a whole universe of Time and Space out there, waiting for us. Well?
I'm ready to leave if you are.
Good.
Controls on console activated.
Let's go, then.
Tardis dematerialisation. Theme music.

We come from another galaxy, a galaxy that has known only war for millennia. But finally the fighting was over. Finally the treaty was signed for the cessation of all biological warfare. During the decommissioning there was an accident. Countless viruses and biological agents engineered for every conceivable purpose were released and scattered across the cosmos. Particles carrying disease and death in a myriad of forms, spreading ever outward across the stars.
Boom, whooshes.
One such particle entered the atmosphere of Grallista Social - an invisible mutagenic particle - and you, Peri, became Patient Zero, infected by it.
Peri coughing, choking.
You haven't tasted it yet.
No, it's not... (coughs) that. Ugh. I think I've just swallowed a fly or something.

The virus copies the host DNA, and when it has finished this process it transmits through particles breathed out of Patient Zero's lungs. It attempts to mutate the DNA of the victim into that of Patient Zero, then transmits rapidly from victim to victim, spreading across entire worlds in a matter of days. The genetic mutation is crude and destructive. As a result, after the initial mutation, each victim dies a slow and painful death.
Did you... did you save them? All those people I saw. The Doctor?
Yes. Our purpose is to track down and neutralise every single particle of those deadly viruses, and expunge all knowledge of our terrible mistake.
So you're a kind of biological clean-up team?
No one must ever possess the knowledge to produce such weapons again. We owe that to the cosmos. We now have no more time here. We are called to another incursion.
You people are doing this all the time then, all across the universe.
That is why you and the Doctor must be expunged.
I can forget this. I can see how important it is. I... I want to forget it. I mean it.
Then we will try to achieve memory zero, one last time.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
PERI: Is this... death? Is this what it feels like to die? (rapid beeping) Somehow I thought it'd be... quieter.
DOCTOR: What is it, Hayton? What's wrong?
HAYTON: The girl's vital signs are flat-lining. Something must have happened in her dream, some trauma or shock.
DOCTOR: Then we have to do something.
HAYTON: Stop that, Doctor. You could do more damage than good.
DOCTOR: I can't just stand here and do nothing.
HAYTON: That's exactly what you have to do. I'm not interested in keeping this specimen alive. I need to see what happens when brain death occurs, how the plant reacts.
DOCTOR: You're inhuman.
HAYTON: Look who's talking. Now step away or regrettably I'll be forced to shoot you.
DOCTOR: What?
HAYTON: Keep your hands where I can see them.
DOCTOR: I thought you were a man of science.
HAYTON: I thought you were too.
TAKOL: Pick the gun up, Doctor. I only set mine to stun, so he could come to at any moment.
DOCTOR: What are you doing here, Major?
TAKOL: The idiot left the vid-link active, I heard every treacherous word that escaped his boastful lips.
DOCTOR: Well, they say pride comes before a fall. Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to help Peri. What have we here? Ah, adrenalin. Forty ccs should do it.
TAKOL: Will that help?
DOCTOR: We'll have to wait and see. What will you do with the Professor now?
TAKOL: He'll be relieved of duty and confined to quarters. He can be put on the brig when we get to the mothership.
DOCTOR: You're leaving?
TAKOL: Got to get off this rock before nightfall.
DOCTOR: Peri. Can you hear me, Peri?
TAKOL: How is she?
DOCTOR: Stabilising. Her vital signs are recovering, but I need to get into her dream.
TAKOL: Let's get the Professor here safely locked away, then we can see what can be done to help your friend.
PERI: Where am I?
MIKE: Outside the house, honey. You were lucky. The car only glanced you.
PERI: What? It hit me full-on. I... I felt it. I was as good as dead.
MIKE: Looking good for a corpse, kiddo.
PERI: Where is Ally?
MIKE: Calling for an ambulance to take you to the hospital. Don't worry. Everything's going to be okay.
ERIMEM: Where are you taking me?
UKARME: There's something I want to show you. Here.
ERIMEM: A door? Believe me, I've seen one before.
UKARME: You won't have seen what's inside before.
ERIMEM: The sign says Keep Out - Quarantine Area.
UKARME: Don't worry, it's safe. Come on.
HAYTON: This is ridiculous. You can't lock me up like this.
TAKOL: Watch me.
HAYTON: I'm well-connected. You're making a big mistake.
TAKOL: No, Professor, it is you who have made a mistake. I am in command of this mission and I will not tolerate any insubordination. Goodbye.
HAYTON: [OC]: Takol!
DOCTOR: I've taken Peri to the lab. Will Hayton be secure in there?
TAKOL: As long as we're not here after nightfall.
DOCTOR: What happens after dark?
TAKOL: The monsters come out.
DOCTOR: I take it that's not a metaphorical statement?
TAKOL: This planet has a diurnal cycle that lasts about a hundred and fourteen hours. During the day it's a
TAKOL: lovely place if you can stomach the heat, the mud slides and the murderous plants, but at night, it's something else.
DOCTOR: How long have we got before sunset?
TAKOL: The shuttle's due to land in half an hour. We evacuate fifteen minutes later.
DOCTOR: Then we don't have much time. I have to get Peri out of that dream state.
UKARME: This is the remains of the original expedition to this horrible planet.
ERIMEM: What happened here? It's like a disaster zone.
UKARME: The base was overrun by those Jekyll things that live in the jungle.
ERIMEM: Like that creature in the laboratory? It didn't seem hostile.
UKARME: Not everything is what it seems, Erimem.
ERIMEM: Who are you, Ukarme? What's really going on here?
DOCTOR: Right, I'll make the connections, but I'll need you to inject me with the plant extract.
TAKOL: I think I can manage that.
DOCTOR: It's vitally important that no attempt is made to wake either of us during this procedure. It could be very dangerous.
TAKOL: Understood.
DOCTOR: And will you check on Erimem for me? I'm not sure where she's got to.
TAKOL: Don't worry, Doctor. Ukarme's probably showing her the base, but I'll make sure she's safe.
DOCTOR: Thank you. Now, let's get on with this. The sooner I can start interfacing with Peri, the sooner I can help her.
TAKOL: Roll up your sleeve, then.
ANNOUNCER: [TV]: Previously on Love MD.
CARLA: [TV]: Clamp. Clamp! What's wrong with you? Do you want this kid to bleed to death? Guido?
MIKE: The doctor says you were really lucky. Hardly a mark on you. You can leave here tonight.
